name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: We can now move on to the discussions on our agenda and, as you know, we begin with a joint debate on the statements of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, to whom I thank for their presence, statements concerning the consequences of the CRISIS of COVID-19 for foreign policy (2020/2646(RSP)), also on the national security law of the People's Republic of China for Hong Kong and the european union's need to defend hong kong's high degree of autonomy (2020/2665(RSP)) and the European Union's response to Israel's possible annexation of the West Bank (2020/2687(RSP)). I would like to remind members that in this joint debate there will be no catch-the-eye procedures or questions in the form of a 'blue card'. Having said that, I would like to speak to Mr Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Mr Borrell, whom I would like to thank you for your presence once again.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vicepresidente de la Comisión / Alto Representante de la Unión para Asuntos Exteriores y Política de Seguridad. – Señor presidente, señoras y señores diputados, Mr President, we have three issues to discuss. I will go directly to the three of them. First, from the European Union response to the coronavirus crisis, it’s clear that the global pandemic needs global solutions, and the European Union must be at the centre of the response. To do so, in April we launched a Team Europe response to support our partner countries facing the pandemic. I have already presented this in your committee meetings. On 8 June, we discussed at the Foreign Affairs Council on Development how to move forward quickly and we mobilised EUR 35 billion to help the most vulnerable countries in Africa, Latin America and our neighbourhood. One could say that it is not fresh money but just redirecting already—allocated resources, but anyway, it was very important to give priority to the pandemic. The extension of the key European Union programmes for refugees is also crucial during this crisis, and we appreciate Parliament’s efforts to approve the necessary Draft Amending Budget in July to allocate more than EUR 400 million in support of Syrian refugees. In the new MMF proposal, we have included a top-up for external action policies, financed through the Next Generation European Union instrument. Part of this funding will go to humanitarian aid, and part to the provision of a higher ceiling for the External Action Guarantee under the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI).  We have also provided for an additional provisioning of EUR 10.5 billion, and with that, we could provide guarantees up to EUR 130 billion under European Fund for Sustainable Development Plus (EFSD+) operations, as well as additional macro-financial assistance and loans to third countries. This will allow us to help to boost sustainable and green investment in our partner countries worldwide. I hope I can count on your support so that we can maintain an ambitious level of resources for our EU external action. Let me say that it is badly needed – because this crisis will be a crisis of biblical consequences. Look at the situation, for example, in Latin America, where things are becoming worse. Happily, in Africa, things are not as bad as expected. But, in general, both health and economic consequences of this crisis will be very important and, I am afraid, long lasting.  The second issue in our debate today is about the People’s Republic of China and the national security law for Hong Kong. Let me frame my answer on a very evident fact. COVID has accelerated existing trends, with tensions between China and the US growing by the day, and I want to repeat what I have already said and written many times: that Europe needs to find its own way when it comes to balancing its relations towards both actors. Yesterday, the French Minister of Foreign Relations was saying more or less the same thing in the French press and I think it’s quite a shared point of view at the Foreign Affairs Council. But independence does not mean equidistance. The transatlantic partnership remains the most important and strategic relationship for the European Union. We maintain divergences with the current administration in the US, that’s clear, evident, with regard to their stand on multilateralism about the International Criminal Court, for example, the last one. Nevertheless, we seek positive engagement wherever possible.  Our relationship with China does not fit into a single category. I am sorry for the people who would like to have simple schemes. This is not possible. This is complex, and complex it will remain, and it needs to be based on trust, transparency and reciprocity. China is clearly a necessary partner, like it or not, to solve global challenges such as the global pandemic and climate change. No one can imagine that we can solve climate change without a strong commitment from China’s side. At the same time, human rights remain a contentious issue in our relations. I raised these concerns on the situation in Hong Kong with the Chinese Foreign Minister last week. We had a long conversation: more than three hours face to face. I think it was a useful and frank conversation about all issues of a complex relationship and, for sure, the adoption of a security law for Hong Kong is not in conformity with China’s international commitments, particularly under the Sino-British Joint Declaration enshrined in the Basic Law of Hong Kong. Pressure on Hong Kong’s autonomy and fundamental freedoms affect us directly. It’s not just a matter for the Hong Kong people. It’s a matter of values, principles and the need to uphold international commitments, seriously undermining the ‘one country, two systems’ principle and Hong Kong’s autonomy. As you may be aware, I made this point very clear in my declaration on behalf of the EU27 on 22 and 29 May. On that issue, there was unanimity, something that is less and less frequent in the debates at the Foreign Affairs Council. I also raised these matters in the United Nations Security Council when I had the opportunity to address this body, on the very day this decision was adopted. I am at your disposal during the question and answers to discuss the specific measures taken by the EU and to go deeper into this issue.  On the third point, on the possible Israeli annexation in the West Bank: let me turn now to this issue, the possible annexation by Israel of parts of the occupied Palestinian territory. There, our position is clear, although, once again, it’s difficult to find unanimity. But there is very much a strong majority of countries that continue supporting a negotiated two-state solution based on international parameters and considering that any annexation would be against international law. Consequently, we strongly urge Israel to refrain from any unilateral decisions that would lead to this annexation of any part of occupied Palestinian territory. I had the opportunity of expressing this point of view in my phone calls to the new Ministers of Foreign Affairs and of Defence of Israel. This would constitute a serious violation of international law. In March, in Geneva, 27 Member States agreed on that. At the last Foreign Affairs Council, unhappily, unanimity was not found on this same issue, but as I said, very much a strong majority of countries continue to support this principle.  Second, this would cause real damage to the prospects for a two-state solution. Third, it would negatively affect regional stability, our relations with Israel, and between Israel and Arab states, and potentially the security of Israel, which is something not negotiable for us. Let me stress that also. And finally, from a European Union perspective, annexation would inevitably have significant consequences for the close relationship we currently enjoy with Israel.  My time is reaching the end. I will stick to my time. I will not prejudge today the specific impact of a possible annexation, but let me underline that the European Union has its own obligations and responsibilities under international and European law, and as agreed in the mid-May Foreign Affairs Council, we engage with our Israeli partners to avoid such a step before it’s too late. We are using all our diplomatic capacities in order to put pressure for that not to happen. As I said, I opened a constructive conversation with Alternate Prime Minister Gantz and Foreign Minister Ashkenazi, where I expressed in the same terms as I explained to you the gravity of such an announcement. I have also been in close contact with the Palestinian leadership and other key Arab representatives. Several EU Foreign Ministers passed the same messages on, and we held an important discussion with the US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo earlier this week. This issue took an important part of the one-and-a-half-hour discussion with Mike Pompeo. In the coming weeks and months, we will continue engaging with the parties and the international community in support of a negotiated two-state solution based on the international parameters and which ensures equal rights for all.  Thank you very much, Mr President, for giving me half a minute more. Thank you for your attention. I need to stop here. I think my time is over, but I will remain at your disposal for the many issues I am sure you will raise during our dialogue.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Thank you very much, Mr Vice-President, for the statements on very important topics, all of them.

name: David McALLISTER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, as I am convinced that we should stand up for fostering the European Union strategic autonomy for promoting multilateral solutions and for defending our interests in a spirit of solidarity, I welcome today’s debate on the foreign policy consequences of the COVID—19 pandemic.  We all know that this pandemic will not only lead to more medical, social and economic changes of a tremendous dimension, but it will also, as the High Representative and Vice—President, Josep Borrell, has pointed out, also be a potential geopolitical game changer. To name just a few examples, we are witnessing the deterioration of democracy and fundamental freedoms in many parts of the world, increasing disinformation campaigns, as well as cyber—attacks and isolationism instead of multilateral cooperation. As the European Parliament, we should make clear that unprecedented global threats arising from the pandemic call for strong and coordinated measures.  I welcome that, in the months and weeks to come, all the committees for external policies in our Parliament want to focus even more on our global response. With today’s debate, but also with upcoming hearings as well as the reports the respective committees are working on, hopefully we can highlight the importance of the foreign policy dimension for the fight against a global pandemic and we can send a strong signal of solidarity with our partners across the world.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the implications of COVID—19 on foreign affairs are multiple; from international relations and trade development to the future of the multilateral order in general. We have to take up full responsibility to lead the global fight against the pandemic that will be based on our core values and principles. Our priorities should be to assist the most vulnerable communities, promote access to the vaccine, support a ceasefire and keep medical equipment and food supply chains open for everybody. At the same time, we cannot set aside our interests. This is why the fight against disinformation has to be our priority. We welcome the new communication and expect it to boost our resilience. Finally, in a sincere multilateralist spirit of close cooperation with key global institutions such as the UN, the WHO and the G20, we must act to help our international partners dealing with the consequences of this pandemic and lead the way towards sustainable development as a core principle for recovery.

name: Malik AZMANI
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, at the start of its mandate, the European Commission announced its geopolitical ambition. Europe was to become a global player. The Coronavirus is putting this ambition to the test. In the last few months, the virus has forced our world to become smaller, keeping us locked down in our houses. And yet, this virus has become a global challenge reaching all corners of the world. It has shown us how connected and interdependent we have become.  However, it seems it is idealistic to think we can globally unite to face this crisis. It is disheartening to see examples where countries have attempted to use COVID-19 to divide Europe and even to act against our interests through so-called Corona diplomacy, disinformation campaigns, and with the escalation of tensions in, for example, Libya and at the Chinese-Indian border. We have to realise that the world keeps turning fast.  It is vital Europe starts acting in a more assertive way to face the challenges ahead with a clear and unified voice in the global arena. This is the moment for the Commission to live up to its geopolitical ambition, leading the search for answers on finding the origins of the virus, leading the global community in the search for a vaccine that will need to be made available to all people and countries, and leading the way to protect European interests, together with our liberal democratic allies in the world.  In the absence of global leadership by the United States, the European Union has to fill this void. Therefore, I call on everyone here present to embrace this global opportunity and responsibility. The European Union can make a difference if it decides to take its seat at the table on the world stage with renewed determination.

name: Marco DREOSTO
text: On behalf of the ID Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Vice-President Borrell, it is clear that the crisis caused by the Covid-19 pandemic is clearly changing global geopolitical balances. In this context, China has certainly not acted as a reliable partner during the health crisis and initial silence cannot be forgiven.  We strongly reiterate, as our secretary Matteo Salvini has repeatedly requested, the need for an international investigation to understand the causes and origins of the virus. The Communist regime has its faults and the European Union must have the strength to demand this investigation. You see, you may feel that you are being told by someone in the League, but you, as High Representative, have had more clarity with regard to China than, alas, the Italian Government. Too many voices, especially from the 5 Star Movement, including Foreign Minister Luigi Di Maio, did not have the strength and courage to condemn Beijing, risking putting Italy in the orbit of China's vassal countries.  We strongly call for this investigation. We will soon see the difference between those who are free and those who are not, between those who choose freedom and those who, on the other hand, see the Chinese Communist Party as a model to follow.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Mr Borrell, colleagues, the fundamental crisis, which has captivated the globe is driven by the COVID-19 pandemic. But it’s also characterised by two novel features.  It’s the first international crisis, since decades, in which the United States withdraws from any possible international leadership role, while China has been at the centre of this crisis, more than ever before, and this is not for the better.  This situation reflects the ongoing continental drift in international relations. On the one hand, we have a hegemonic battle between two superpowers, on the other, international institutions are being weakened - in particular multilateral institutions - and undermined. Through the impact of the crisis, these tendencies are being accelerated. For our EU this constitutes an imperative to step up to the plate and to shoulder our own international obligations more confidently.  We have a mixed record. We failed when we imposed import-export bans for PPEs. We did well when the Commission organised a donors’ conference for financing vaccine research and we will lead a coalition at the WHO to require an inquiry into the origin and the spread of the pandemic. But the challenges are many and they are huge. Battling for our values and our interests means finding allies and showing our opponents that we mean business.  And let me end by making a remark regarding Hong Kong. I welcome the recent statement by the G7.  Through our resolution, this EP will say that the EU will not just criticise. We want China to understand that reneging on international obligations doesn’t come free of cost. This message should be shared with Chinese leaders at the EU summit on Monday.

name: Witold Jan WASZCZYKOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Señor Borrell! 20 years ago, Polish Foreign Minister and the US Secretary of State launched the Community of Democracy, a grand coalition of world democracies, in Warsaw. It was on the 20th anniversary of Polish initiative that President Andrzej Duda was invited to the White House as the first European leader to visit the United States after a pandemic. Presidents will, of course, talk about bilateral relations, but also about how to reborn transatlantic cooperation. Europe should work together for transatlantic cooperation – not to divide the community, not to separate from the United States, not to choose between the United States and China. Together in the face of the virus, the crisis and the security challenges. I therefore appeal to you, Señor Borrell, and to the European External Action Service, to join the Polish President's efforts to revive transatlantic cooperation.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the We've been talking about Corona for months now. And this pandemic shows very clearly what mistakes prevail in the economic and political system. For decades, the EU's dogma has been: private before state. On the one hand, in the period from 2011 to 2018 alone, we have called on Member States to make cuts and privatisations in the health sector 63 times. On the other hand, there is an obligation to steadily increase military spending under PESCO. Mr Borrell, millions of Europeans face major social challenges, losing their jobs or part of their income. It is precisely for the first time that you want to spend more than EUR 25 billion in the EU budget on research and procurement of war equipment – even though Article 41(2) expressly prohibits this. Why wouldn't you want to understand that you can't eat bombs and tanks and that you can't take care of people in good health? They say: we need hard skills. The time of naive Europe is over. I say: naive to believe that this spiral of armament and this updated geopolitical orientation will bring more peace and security.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President, the European Union must show the world that it is unacceptable to use the fight against the pandemic as an excuse to weaken the rule of law. Now more than ever, the Union's foreign policy needs to be presided over by its founding values: the defence of human rights and democratic freedoms. And it is necessary that the representatives of the Union to the world be able to credifie these principles. This week we have known CIA documents from the 1980s stating that the Spanish government, chaired by Felipe González, agreed to form a group of mercenaries, the GAL, to combat terrorism outside the law. Put simply: state terrorism. And in 1998 you publicly showed your solidarity with a minister and a secretary of state a few days after you were sentenced to prison for the case. (The president interrupts the speaker).)

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Please ask the speaker to respect the issues that are on our agenda because otherwise the intervention subverts the agenda that is established. Would you finish your speech, please?

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Mr High Representative, with all personal respect, but with all the ethical demand and with all the political force, I ask you: do you confirm your support for those responsible for state terrorism? Its response depends not only on its legitimacy to act as a high representative but on the credibility of the Union as a whole with the international community.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: I would remind all colleagues that an agenda has been agreed with three topics for our discussion and that, of course, interventions on topics that are not on the agenda represent a subversion of the agenda that is affixed. Therefore, I ask you to respect the agenda of our meeting.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The economic consequences of the COVID-19 crisis are further destabilising states and entire regions that are already affected by crises and conflicts. Some actors are trying to get their planned agenda through in the shadow of the crisis without attracting much attention. We should oppose this! China must be reminded that the agreement with the United Kingdom on Hong Kong is an agreement binding under international law – deposited with the United Nations – and not a historic document. It is good that political representatives from Europe are now travelling to Israel or are maintaining dialogue by video, in particular to make it clear to the Head of Government that annexations that are contrary to international law can also have unexpected consequences of various kinds from near and far. Please hold back! In countries with transformation, such as Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova, we must call out all those who want to consolidate their own oligarchic interests in the shadow of the crisis: the EU stands by the true reformers and implements with them the agreed cooperation and reform agenda.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, Vice-President Borrell, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work Even without Corona, this year would be a year of the worst human disasters on the globe in decades. Whereas only a few years ago there were 80 million people at risk of imminent starvation, even without Corona this year it would be 120-130 million people. Environmental disasters and military conflicts make the difference. Corona will double this number: more than 260 million people are directly affected by hunger, mass deaths. It is good that we mobilised funds very quickly, but do you have a number, an order of magnitude of collective effort, that will be needed to prevent mass extinction so that we know what we are talking about this year? Can you tell us a sentence on the sanctions policy against Iran, against Venezuela?  I do not want to open up the full range of political debate, but it is certainly the case that the European Union must do everything possible to combat the pandemic and hunger there too, no matter what other international actors think about it.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: – Mr President, Mr Borrell, dear colleagues, we have focused our efforts on the COVID-19 pandemic as a health crisis in recent months. But in its shadow a human rights crisis is unfolding and this human rights crisis is making the health emergency even worse.  If regimes attack and kidnap journalists who report on the pandemic, it doesn’t stop the virus, it just spreads disinformation and mistrust. If regimes use corona funds to buy weapons for their police to enforce lockdowns, it doesn’t stop the virus. It only spreads fear and death.  Of course, restrictions to individual freedoms are necessary to fight the pandemic, but each and every restriction needs to be proportionate. It needs to be clearly linked to the health emergency and above all, people have to be allowed to debate them and often they are not.  So, to fight the COVID-19 crisis globally, we need to tackle both the health emergency and the human rights crisis. We need to monitor the spread of the disease and the human rights violations. We need to investigate deaths and human rights violations. We need to protect our doctors and our human rights defenders. Mr Borrell, it’s not just about millions. Team Europe needs to become Team Human Rights. And while I applaud your efforts in this regard, and you have spoken up strongly, I really think that we need to step up our actions on this one as well, looking at the world of today.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Firstly, I would like to thank the former, Minister Waszczykowski, for his approval of the Community of Democracy, a movement initiated by Minister Bronisław Geremek and continued by me. I hope that this means that the Polish will also stop violating the rule of law and return to the role of Polish as an example of democratisation to be imitated by others.  And with regard to the pandemic, I believe that a real reshuffle in the hierarchy of countries will come as a result of how we deal with the financial and economic crisis. The Commission's proposals offer great hope that we will do better and that the Union will be more coherent. But at the same time, the policy of artificially low interest rates will continue, resulting in increased inequality in our countries. So we have a great opportunity, but also a great threat. And I hope that your service will also monitor these matters.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Borrell that, as you mentioned yourself, the impact of the COVID—19 crisis on the international stage isn’t yet fully clear, but it will be huge. That’s for sure. Let me take the example of China because it’s in front of us of course. Even before the pandemic, we had huge problems in our relationship with China. I am thinking about human rights, trade relations and the fact that it’s a state-led economy, just to mention a few. During the COVID crisis these problems have only increased. They have bombarded Europe with fake news, they were not transparent on how to deal with the COVID crisis within their country, and there was of course the knowledge that we now have that we are too dependent on China, for instance for protective material when it comes to a health crisis. So let’s be very clear, Mr Borrell. Trade policy is the most important and the most powerful tool that we have within foreign policy and we need to bind them together, not just paying lip service to human rights and at the same time having normal trade relations with China. We need to fundamentally rethink how we look at China.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, I would like to highlight three aspects, briefly, of the external dimension of COVID—19. On the one hand, the crisis has highlighted the shortcomings of global health governance. International institutions have not been able to effectively ensure eer the exchange of information or coordination in the fight against the virus. The second point I would like to underline is the exaggerated European dependence on the outside world. We must achieve a high level of health autonomy. We cannot continue to depend on third countries in strategic areas such as obtaining sanitary material or active pharmaceutical ingredients for the manufacture of medicines. Currently, suffice it to note that 80% of the world's production of these pharmaceutical ingredients is concentrated in India and China. On the other hand, it is clear that we must help third countries, especially our African neighbours, in their fight against the crisis and, therefore, I welcome the that the Union's response has made an important financial contribution to the fight against the pandemic in third countries. And I'm done. Unfortunately, pandemic outbreaks have occurred over the past two decades. Incomprehensibly, the latter of COVID—19 has caught us by surprise, again. We live in a globalized and hyperconnected world. Viruses know no borders. The next health crisis must be addressed in a more coordinated and effective way.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, Mr High Representative. The truth is that the pandemic has not only meant the greatest health and economic challenge of the last century for humanity, but has underlined the enormous weaknesses and contradictions of our current model of international governance. Probably trends we've seen before: a clamorous lack of global leadership, very weakened multilateral organizations, and a worrying—and huge risk—tension between great powers. But Europe can also draw a few lessons on how to act abroad now.  More than ever, we need Europe to take responsibility for revitalizing and reforming multilateral structures because cooperation is necessary for global challenges such as the pandemic, such as climate change, inequality or putting standards to globalization; and competition is useless to us. And Europe has to find its own autonomous path as the only way to defend its values and interests in the world.  A moment also to seek allies and support them at times like today, such as Latin America, which right now is suffering severely from the consequences of the pandemic.

name: Alexander ALEXANDROV YORDANOV
text: – Mr President, Mr Borrell, let us congratulate the citizens of Hong Kong who defend their rights and freedoms trampled by China's Parliament following the adoption of the repressive national security law. As a representative of a country that has experienced the horror of totalitarian Communist rule, I call on the Commission and the Council, as well as all MEPs, to part with the illusion that communist China and I can build friendly relations.  We must vigorously defend the freedoms of hong kong citizens. Our values require us to make it clear to the Beijing regime that we are able to terminate investment deals with it, limit our trade relations, and we can implement a policy of sanctions against its functionaries, as we did after Russian aggression against Ukraine.  Sanctions are the only peaceful tool to insize survivors of 21st-century communist dinosaurs.

name: Miriam LEXMANN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, if one is not ready to speak for freedom everywhere, we cannot expect freedom to be granted anywhere. China continues to subvert Hong Kong’s autonomy, rule of law and fundamental freedoms, as well as international agreements. The latest unilateral decision by the National People’s Congress of China to enact a national security law for Hong Kong seriously threatens the city’s autonomy, rule of law and fundamental freedoms. It is expected that the law will introduce a range of vague and draconian charges.  Two weeks ago, over 900 political leaders worldwide, including many of you, made a joint statement condemning this move. The joint motion for a resolution of this Parliament provides a clear and principled stance on the situation in Hong Kong and upholds the values on which this Union has been built, and which should and must direct our foreign policy, as stipulated in Article 21 of the Treaty. I therefore call on all Members to support this resolution and to stand with the people of Hong Kong.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, since the signing of the Sino-British Declaration for the transfer of Hong Kong, many of the region's inhabitants feared the day when the Chinese Government would ignore the basic law and make a clear plank of fundamental rights, as it has done in Tibet, Xinjiang and a bit throughout China. With the decision to impose national security law on Hong Kong, the Chinese Government paved the way for disrespect for the rule of law and called into question the principle of 'one country, two systems'. The abuses of the Chinese Government and the emphasis of repression cannot be tolerated. The importance of the strategic relationship between the European Union and China cannot mean a lesser demand for coherence between our action and our values. On the contrary, it imposes on us the demanding defence of freedom, human rights, hong kong autonomy and international law. That is what is expected of the European Union.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, it is very clear for me. I defend the ‘one country, two systems’ principle so I stand with the people of Hong Kong and support their freedom of expression. The arrest of four democratic leaders, the violent crackdown on protestors and the new security law are an assault on the autonomy of Hong Kong.  Luckily, this Parliament is united in a very strong resolution, asking China to withdraw the security law, to respect the freedom of people in Hong Kong and to show that it is willing to respect the rule of law. If not, we, the international community, should consider a case before the International Court of Justice and Magnitsky—style sanctions. Mr Borrell, let me stress that, with almost 500 million consumers of Chinese products, we have the necessary economic leverage to make a change. I want Europe to engage with China. I want Europe to look for a new China strategy. But we have to do this by defending our values and our interests. That’s why I plead again to China: withdraw the security law and give the people of Hong Kong the autonomy that has been agreed upon in the ‘one country, two systems’ agreement. Our group, Renew, stands for democracy values everywhere in the world.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Communist China is the empire of evil of the third millennium. China's Communist dictatorship is the greatest threat to our freedom and democracy. The coronavirus emergency, the war against Hong Kong in violation of international law and Chinese spies within the European institutions are facts that clearly demonstrate this.  It is scandalous that Europe and the Italian government of PD and 5 Stars are silent accomplices in the misdeeds of the Chinese regime. No more silences, no more double games, no more lies! Europe must demand the truth about the crimes committed by China. Our lives and values are not for sale in exchange for some blood- dirty business.  Ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that we are facing an economic war and a war of civilisation that the Chinese dictatorship has declared against the Western world. We stand firmly with the Atlantic Alliance and we must be prepared to defend our freedom and democracy by all means. Italians, Europeans and free men from all over the world will never die slaves to the Chinese Communist regime.

name: Assita KANKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, this Commission has promised to be a geopolitical Commission. Yet, so far, I have not seen proof of this. Instead, I’ve seen the External Action Service bend over backwards to appease Beijing. At next week’s EU-China summit, it’s clear that the Chinese are unwilling to make progress on any major issues.  So, I ask the Commission, I’m asking you why are you giving Beijing a free photo op while they use all their energy to wage a global campaign against democracy? The people of Hong Kong were promised their own system of governance. China is reneging on its promises with the national security law.  If you are to truly defend democracy at home and abroad, we cannot just issue statements of support for Hong Kong democratic forces. We must back up our words with actions. The EU is trying to chart its own strain of strategy. I do not subscribe to some of the Cold War rhetoric that we have seen from Washington. But, as Margaret Thatcher once said: ‘The trouble with walking down the middle of the road is you get hit by traffic in both directions.’ Where do you want to stand?

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, yesterday we spoke in this Parliament about the death of George Floyd. It is necessary to hear the green MEP talk about racist harassment. And today I want to remember the twenty thousand deaths in the Mediterranean since 2014, fifty-three deaths and disappearances just ten days ago. The European Union needs to do its duties respecting human rights in our territory and have independence to demand responsibility for all the George Floyds in the world. We need to strengthen governance structures in order to have a foreign policy based on disarmament, based on mediation, end of sanctions, multilateralism, the fight against climate change and gender equity. In Hong Kong this is about defending the right to demonstrate peacefully, as we ask from Chile to Palestine, from Ecuador to Lebanon. Encourage dialogue, respect the terms of the Sino-British agreement, but also denounce continued interference from Trump or the British government. We must bet on a comprehensive relationship of the European Union with China based on mutual cooperation, in which agreements can be discussed but also differences. As everywhere in the world, we need more than just a free trade agreement that leaves human rights out.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Mr President, the EU’s objective on Hong Kong is to make China respect Hong Kong. Respecting Hong Kong means respecting international law and particularly the right to self-determination. Making China respect Hong Kong will open the door for a greater respect of human rights in all the country and so will offer hope to people like the Uyghurs today victims of a tragic ethnic and religious persecution. If, on the contrary, the EU fails in this purpose, if the EU just makes grandstanding rhetoric and photoshop diplomacy, covering up the more unpleasant side of this great economic partner of ours, China, the discussion will be not on the concept of one country-two systems, but the EU will have shown yet again that it has one set of principles, two standards. Let me say that I don’t trust much in this diplomacy that has shown its docility in confronting China’s pressures but, Mr Josep Borrell, I’m ready to be surprised.

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: – Mr President, really, of course, we are condemning what Chinese authorities are doing against democracy and against Chinese international obligations in Hong Kong. We are standing together with the Hong Kong people in defence of their rights and their autonomy. Of course, you should place strong pressure on Beijing next week, but we can see some paradoxes in the actions of the Chinese authorities. The attempts to destroy the democracy of Hong Kong brings clear evidence that they are afraid of that small island of democracy. Usually weak authorities are showing that they are afraid, and it reminds me of how the Soviet Union collapsed. The Soviet Union had weak authority and they were afraid of democracy. Chinese people are really clever people, and prudent people, and China deserves to be allowed into global leadership, but they need to learn now not to be afraid of democracy, and they need to learn democracy from Hong Kong and Taiwan.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, the US Senate unanimously passed the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act last November, designed to protect US business interests. Sadly, the protest movement in Hong Kong has been hijacked by Washington-sponsored protesters who have turned justified anti-neoliberalism corruption protest into anti-China protests, fuelled by xenophobia and racism. The National Endowment for Democracy, an engine of US regime change machine, has recruited Hong Kong opposition leaders to orchestrate the protests and poured millions of dollars into them. Meanwhile in the US, they have a brutal far-right administration that lynches its black and brown people every day, brutalises protesters in the streets, imprisons, disenfranchises and pushes into forced labour more people than any country on earth. There are more black people in the American incarceration system today than there were slaves in 1850. This is the system that sings the praises of the violence of the Hong Kong protesters.  This is our third plenary debate on Hong Kong. When are we going to have one on Yemen? This Parliament needs to stop being a lapdog to a lawless US government.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, I wonder what we are doing here or whether this Parliament has Nostradamus skills, because we are advancing debates on an issue, in the case of Israel, which has not yet happened. I don't know what we're doing here today debating the issue of Israel. Honestly, I mean, of course, that we are here summoned by the ultra-left, the communists.  I would like to thank very reasonable people on the European left, in the Socialist Party and in the Greens, who yesterday were able to differentiate, on the subject of aviation, the political issues from practices for this European Union. Reasonable people, as we are. Why are we debating this? Because of the obsession... There is a companion there from the United Left..., well, anyway, of Podemos's, Idoia Villanueva, who was talking about Chile. Chile has not been a dictatorship for years; however, Iran, Venezuela, Cuba are dictatorships.  I understand your obsession with Israel's democracy. Please change your tone, change your speech now. We are defending, as the high representative has done, that we are talking here of an issue that has not yet had to be discussed.  We can then discuss, when it happens, the alleged annexation. We are not here to discuss election statements but concrete facts, as we will, high representative, in the near future.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, I am a little confused because I have just seen the results of yesterday's vote on the agreement with Israel on air services. I am confused, to the extent that I wonder if our institution is still ready to defend multilateralism. Indeed, I hear many of my colleagues here protest against certain administrations, saying that they are flouting multilateralism, and by the vote we made yesterday. 437 MEPs did not even ask themselves whether or not we respected multilateralism and the decisions of multilateralism.  So, here, my intervention is absolutely not related to the position you are taking, Mr Borrell, because I think you have made courageous decisions on the issue of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but I really wonder about our institution and our ability not to have double language and not to have a double standard. We are talking about China, we are talking about Russia, but when it comes to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, it seems that we are being stripped of an ability to decide something that is ultimately decided on an international level. That is my confusion, Mr. Borrell, i.m. sorry, but I think it is ours as a parliamentary assembly.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, today I would like to express a deep concern here.  Under the coalition agreement that brought him to power, the Israeli government is considering annexing part of the occupied West Bank. This annexation would be illegal, it would be dangerous, it would be the poisonous fruit of a balance of power. However, for us here in Europe, despite all that divides us, one certainty brings us together: this certainty is that force does not give all rights. What brings us together is the conviction that the power of the law must always prevail over the right of the strongest. I say this with great friendship for Israel because friendship imposes duties. I say this because I place my hopes in the wisdom of Israeli democracy. I say this, as my country did when it saw the United States go wrong in 2003 by launching a war in Iraq for the wrong reasons, a war that has had so many negative consequences. The role of a friend is not to be silent, it is to alert the one who risks being misled. All of us here in Europe know that we only make peace with our enemies. You in Israel have the strength for yourself, so use it for peace. Remember what Itzhak Rabin said: only a strong people can make peace with their enemies. Because you are strong, be fair!

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, of course, Israel's announced annexation of the Palestinian territories is a serious violation of international law. And, Mr. Lopez—Istúriz, we want to discuss it now, because we don't want it to happen. We want to prevent a breach of international law. I know that you may not be too interested in protecting international standards, but a majority of this House, and a majority of European Union countries, are interested in protecting international law. So it is a mistake, I think, what was done yesterday not by postponing the vote on the aviation agreement with Israel, because, in the end, if we let this happen without any consequence, what message are we sending? What kind of defense of multilateralism are we expressing as the European Union? And, also, I think it's a very important moment. We were now talking about the need for the weight and voice of the European Union to strengthen in the face of the withdrawal of the United States. If there is one scenario in which the voice of the European Union must be strong now, it is in the face of the serious consequences of Israel's decision in the Middle East. And so I would like to celebrate the blunt communications of European diplomacy, saying that such a step forward will not pass without being answered. That there will be a reaction. Because I think, of course, that now is the time to multiply diplomatic efforts at all levels to prevent this from happening, but if it happens, Israel must also know that this is not going to happen without consequences and that the intense relationship we have with Israel is obviously going to have to be reviewed. And finally, I believe that we must also redouble our efforts and support actions within the framework of the United Nations Security Council so that when this decision happens ⸻and it seems that from 1 July this is going to start happening⸻ that issue will not happen either without being answered at the United Nations.

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Solana, I hope that the Commission and my fellow Members will abide by the facts. There is no arms race, no sudden military operation. We are talking about a legislative proposal to be submitted to the canonical parliamentary passages of a democratic state. So I can only be surprised at these alarmisms, but clearly here in Brussels there are those who have already forgotten how democracy works enough to propose interference in the internal affairs of sovereign states and prepare to put their decision-making authority on trial. It is precisely for this reason that I would remind the institutions that the protagonists of the Middle East peace process should be the State of Israel and the Palestinian Authority, while the European Union has only a supporting role to play in the utmost neutrality. And that's because ambition without tools becomes wishful. Some international analysts have already said that the European Union, Turkey and Iran will bark without biting.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr Barnier, once again, a number of parties are once again targeting Israel unilaterally, while it is far from clear what the new Israeli Government's plans are going to look like. Moreover, the situation is much more complex than is now being suggested by a number of colleagues.  Let us not forget that these are areas which were part of the mandate territory of Palestine at the time – intended for the foundation of a national Jewish home – which were then occupied for years by Jordan and which came under Israeli military control in a defensive war in 1967. And to this day, they still are. For this reason alone, big words about annexation and violation of international law are highly debatable.  Time and time again, the EU makes the mistake of taking sides unilaterally, again and again. If we really want to play a role in resolving the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, we must abandon this one-sidedness as soon as possible. This conflict calls for mediators, not know-it-alls on the sidelines!

name: Manu PINEDA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mr Borrell, in early February you stated that Israel's annexation of Palestinian territories could not pass without opposition from the European Union. As you know, before the pandemic was declared, I was in Palestine as president of the delegation of this Parliament and I must tell you that, despite your clear opposition, that plan is being implemented step by step without us taking any action to hinder it.  The last decision announced by Israel is the most serious so far. We are talking about the annexation of important parts of the West Bank: a third of the West Bank, including the Jordan Valley. An annexation that involves signing the death certificate of a project that has been dying for decades: the two-state solution. Of course, it is impossible not to wonder what the European Union is doing. As we have said many times, his communiqués and statements are impeccable, but time gives us reason. His words don't do much good if you don't move on to the facts. Mr Borrell, some questions I would like you to answer are: What does the European Union expect to recognise the Palestinian State? Why is the Association Agreement not already cancelled, applying the second Article? Why is Israel not prevented from participating in all EU-funded programmes? Why is an arms embargo not imposed on the Israeli regime? Why is trade in products from illegal settlements not prohibited? Mr Borrell, we must take steps to replace the law of the strongest with the law of protection of the weakest. The only empire that must exist is the empire of international law, peace with dignity and social justice.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Mr Joseph Borrell, i would like to thank you for your support. Colleagues in the EPP are wondering what we are doing here today. While the EPP seems to be waiting for an annexation and then be reactive, we in S&D prefer to be active and prevent a possible annexation. If Israel were to proceed with the annexation plans, it would be a major blow to the peace process. The chances of resuming negotiations on the two-state solution would be completely impossible. It would also undermine the situation and strengthen the breeding ground for polarisation, extremism and violence in the region.  An annexation constitutes a violation of international law, as well as a violation of Article 2 of the EU-Israel Association Agreement. But even if the major annexation plans under Trump's plan do not happen, there is actually a step-by-step annexation in the form of expansion of the settler areas of Palestine. My question to you, Mr Vice-President and High Representative, is: what steps do you intend to take towards Netanyahu's annexation plans to show that we are a Union that stands up for fundamental rights in the region, in our Union as well as globally?

name: n/a
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. "Five minutes is enough time to answer 33 speakers. You will understand that my answer cannot be as complete as I would have wished. I am delighted to be involved in this debate, and perhaps it would be good if I could also have the opportunity to interact with you in my answers, I will try to do so as much as possible. Different views have been expressed on Israel, the annexation. Someone has said that it is debatable, whether or not it is in accordance with international law. I can only tell you that there are twenty-five countries of the twenty-seven that believe it is contrary to international law. They'll all be wrong, but that's what they think. Twenty-five countries of twenty-seven have clearly supported a statement that this would be contrary to international law. Why are we talking about this now? Because we're trying to keep it from happening. That we don't know the plans of the Government of Israel? You forgive me. Yes, we do. Of course we do. They are public and notorious, they are part of the coalition agreement. And I myself have been explained live and live ministers of that government. And the German minister, who has gone to Israel, has been told directly. I mean, let's know, we know. Let's not do ostrich politics. No, we don't know. Yes, we know. And what are we doing? We are doing our best to ensure that diplomatically these things do not happen and we do not have to deal with a difficult situation. Why does the European Union not recognize the Palestinian state? Because the European Union does not recognise anyone, it has no capacity to recognise. This is done by the Member States, and each makes the decision it deems appropriate. What measures are to be taken? Well, we'll see. Let's not anticipate. Here, yes; let's not anticipate. Let's try to foresee. But certainly, the majority position, which is not unanimous — unfortunately, I cannot assure you that it is unanimous, because it is not — is that this would be contrary to international law and that it would have to have consequences, and we are trying to prevent it from happening. As for Hong Kong and China, I cannot agree more with you on the need to do everything in our power to ensure that China's international agreements and the system it agreed with the United Kingdom when China left the colony are respected. We do this by defending principles, but also because it is in our interest, and there is intense activity about it. There are more issues in our relationship with China, which we will discuss at the next summit. I've tried to refer to all of them, and so do you, but let us focus on one very important aspect that many of you have pointed out, which is that the crisis has brought with it —I think it was Mr B'tikofer and others who have rightly pointed it out—a crisis of American leadership—the United States has clearly withdrawn from any attempt to lead the global response to the pandemic—a hegemonic battle between the two great powers and a weakness of multinational instances. This is the scenario we're on. And I sincerely believe that Europe cannot fail to ignore this scenario and that it has to have a position of its own. As for strategic autonomy — it has a lot to do with what many of you have also pointed out about our over-reliance on the supply of medicines, and we now realize that our dependence is much greater than we thought and can become critical at critical moments like this—we need to strengthen this strategic autonomy and maintain our values and interests autonomously—and I've strived to explain that it doesn't mean equidistant, but to be very clear about what we want, what we stand for. Because, whether we like it or not, unfortunately, we cannot always agree with the United States, because the United States makes unilateral decisions that we do not share. And since we don't share them, we can't be on their side. For example, we cannot be on your side in the decisions you make regarding the International Criminal Court. And here, I hope That Parliament will agree with this statement. And instead, we have to preserve transatlantic unity in what is always possible, because we share the same political system. That's why we sometimes say that we are China's systemic rivals because we certainly don't share the same political system, but that doesn't mean we have to be rivaling China at all times. Because there are very important issues on which we need joint action, to the extent that it can be agreed. I believe, ladies and gentlemen, that these are the answers. Yes, arms race. No, no one is thinking that let us push for an arms race, but unfortunately there are conflicts that we have to deal with, and unfortunately these conflicts must be confronted with weapons. The next time a group of terrorists storms a village in Mali and kills all its inhabitants at the machine gun point, we will send them the text of a Resolution to invite them not to continue to do so, but I think it is much more efficient than the forces of those countries and ours — which are deployed there to fight terrorism — have the means to do so.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: I inform you that I have received six motions for resolutions submitted in accordance with Article 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Friday [June 19]. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The situation around the covid-19 pandemic is affecting the whole world, and it is clear that the European Union should be as involved as possible both in combating the effects of the virus now and in counteracting its negative effects in the future. International solidarity calls on us to support and help those countries that are most vulnerable, such as many countries on the African continent.   We should make every effort to counter act as much as possible against the increase in tension between China and the United States. The EU should work sustainably with these strategic partners. The current situation only underlines how important this cooperation is. After all, we face global challenges! Poland is an example of building the best transatlantic cooperation possible. Soon, President Polish Andrzej Duda will travel to Washington, D.C., as the first European leader to be invited to the White House after the lockdown to meet with the Us President. There are many common challenges and many topics to discuss. Let us build and cooperate instead of escalating antagonism and escalating tensions.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Hong Kong's success is built on its freedoms. The current actions of the Communist Party of China pose the greatest threat to the inhabitants of autonomy since 1997. We are deeply concerned about Beijing's attempts to unilaterally and arbitrarily impose national security rules, which violates Article 23 of the Hong Kong Basic Law, and violates China's international obligations, including under the UN-notified Sino-UK Agreement. I am pleased that we have been able to negotiate a strong text that clearly describes our position on the actions of the PCC. Its adoption will send a clear signal of how we should shape our relations with Beijing, whose policies have been of concern to me for many years. Beijing's expansion is not at all as peaceful as it is trying to present to the world. Last term, we discussed Chinese military action in the South and East China Seas in detail. I still remember meeting ilham Tohti's daughter, a Uighur scientist and journalist sentenced by the Chinese authorities to life imprisonment. Beijing managed to strangled Tibet some time ago and systematically reaches for new targets. We must support a democratic Taiwan, ensure compliance with international law. That is what today's resolution is about, which I strongly support.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – The pandemic has already led to a number of problems, seriously damaging the economies of our partner countries in our own and western Balkans. These will, of course, reduce our room for manoe d'or more, but it is essential that we do not let go of the hands of our partner countries in times of crisis. They must be kept hopeful by keeping the EU perspective alive, but we must also provide them with financial assistance. It is therefore important that the Western Balkan states receive as much assistance as possible during this period. I welcome the significant support announced by the Enlargement Commissioner to the Western Balkans in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic. The total amount of assistance mobilised by the Enlargement Commissioner is EUR 3.3 billion, of which EUR 38 million is immediate support to the health sector, EUR 389 million is intended for social and economic recovery, EUR 750 million for macro-financial assistance, EUR 455 million for economic recovery and EUR 1.7 billion for preferential loans from the European Investment Bank. With our steps, we have shown that our western Balkan partner countries can count on us during and after the crisis.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. – The coronavirus outbreak will result in a number of problems worldwide that are not yet accurately assessed, including in the health, social and economic fields. While the economic downturn is consensing our available resources, the humanitarian and development needs of our partner countries are also increasing. In order for European responses to be truly successful, we need to take a new approach to development policy. In addition to addressing the immediate humanitarian consequences of the coronavirus epidemic, we must also pay attention to the longer-term, economic and social impact of the epidemic. We must avoid protracted humanitarian crises in regions such as north-east Nigeria, Burkina Faso or South Sudan, which could be the starting point for migration to Europe. This is only possible if humanitarian and development aid is actually delivered to those in need, so that it can be used according to the real needs of the country, region and local communities. In the current economic situation, we need to make use of the available material resources in a more efficient way than before. The credibility of European engagement depends on this. Direct dialogue with local communities in developing countries contributes greatly to improving efficiency. In this work, we can have reliable partners in local churches, which, unfortunately, are often discriminated against in eu development policy. At a time when the citizens of the Union are also in need of support, we simply cannot ignore the development and humanitarian activities carried out by the churches and the reserves they provide.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. – When the British colony of Hong Kong was passed on to China in 1997, it all looked like a formality. Nothing should have changed for hong kongers, and if so, for the better (there was even a commitment to gradual democratization). China, too, was different then. Internationally, it has behaved constructively and continued the pace of reform at home. Hong Kong has been promised permanent autonomy status in the spirit of the "one country, two systems" concept. This period is now over. China's current leadership has a different strategy – it shows more assertiveness on the outside, tightening screws in. A symbolic nail in the coffin of Hong Kong's autonomy is brought by a security law passed this May in the shadow of COVID-19 by china's parliament. The law is intended to allow the suppression of terrorist and separatist activities, subversion and foreign interference. It criminalizes beijing's undermining of authority in Hong Kong, fundamentally undermining Hong Kong's autonomy. It is thus directly directed against the demonstrations and is a reaction to them. A sad reaction that is entirely in the spirit of Chinese methods and thinking. This year, Hong Kongers were still free to commemorate the events in Tiananmen Square in Beijing in 1989. The question is, will it still be possible next year? We must stand up for Hong Kong and not throw its people overboard. It is part of a universal struggle for freedom and human rights.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: Writing. – The State of Israel enjoys disproportionate interest in this Parliament; not as the most democratic country in the Middle East, with which we share a large part of security interests and civilisational values; not as a country that achieves exceptional results in almost every area of human life and from which much can be expected; no, Israel is most often the subject of criticism; criticism that is incomparable to other, perhaps significantly undemocratic, regimes. This is not just about this Parliament, unschedued resolutions deal with Israel more often than all the other states in the world put together. Are they all better? Or is it just a much tougher benchmark against Israel? There can be no doubt that criticism is part of a friendly relationship; however, it is not always advisable to criticize a friend in whose situation we are not even remotely in. Surely the EU should communicate its views and doubts to Israel; however, there are more fragile diplomatic channels than threatening resolutions, as representatives of Austria and Hungary have repeatedly pointed out. Trump's plan is not self-sacriting, but it represents one of the possible paths out of an impasse that the Palestinian Authority itself has repeatedly decided to do in 1947, 1967, 1978, 2000, 2001, 2005, 2007, 2012, and 2015. Unfortunately, the EU's tendency is to see all Israeli splinters and no Palestinian crossbar.
