name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on combating disinformation on COVID-19 and the impact on freedom of expression (2020/2635(RSP)). I would like to point out briefly that no spontaneous speeches or blue cards are accepted in this debate.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the exceptional world health crisis we’re still facing has been aggravated by an unprecedented ‘infodemic’. Our citizens have been flooded by often false or inaccurate information, which not only creates confusion but is also putting health and lives at risk.  To address these risks the Council has strongly emphasised the need to intensify joint efforts in the fight against disinformation through close cooperation between EU institutions, Member States and social platforms. There is consensus in the Council about the need for more effective methods to address disinformation without hindering the protection of fundamental rights. Indeed, our strong and coordinated action against disinformation must be in line with our democratic values, including freedom of expression and free and plural media.  All institutions, Member States and civil society are called to act against the plague of the infodemic. Much has been done in the EU institutions, in cooperation with Member States. The External Action Service’s StratCom Task Force and the rapid alert system, which was set up in the run-up to the European elections last year, track disinformation. We support and welcome these efforts.  A comprehensive approach at all levels is needed to address the challenges of disinformation. This must include monitoring and analysis of disinformation and manipulative interfaces, enforcement of European data protection rules, efforts to enhance pluralistic media, professional journalism and media literacy, as well as awareness among citizens.  EU institutions and Member States should continue working with social media platforms to achieve higher standards of responsibility, transparency and accountability on addressing disinformation. The whole society approach is also stressed by the recent Joint Communication ‘Tackling COVID—19 disinformation – Getting the facts right’, which takes stock of the measures taken in response to disinformation around the coronavirus pandemic and proposes further action.  The Presidency takes COVID-19 disinformation very seriously and we have taken steps to ensure close cooperation with Member State authorities, with EU institutions, bodies and agencies, and with international organisations such as the WHO. As early as 28 January, we activated the European Union’s integrated political crisis response arrangements regarding the COVID-19 pandemic, bringing together relevant experts from the Member States and the EU institutions in the fields of health, consular affairs and civil protection. In this framework, disinformation has been one of the topics we addressed. We believe that disinformation campaigns could also be highly disruptive in the respect of easing restrictive measures and of searching for a vaccine and a cure. We have also addressed the issue in other parliaments, such as in our Horizontal Working Party on Enhancing Resilience and Countering Hybrid Threats, in the Political and Security Committee and in the EU–US Justice and Home Affairs ministerial videoconference.  We are conscious that disinformation is here to stay and we all need to work together to maintain our vigilance, strengthen our toolbox and resilience, and continue our efforts to address this issue internally and beyond our EU borders. COVID—related disinformation is aggravating existing divisions in the eastern and southern neighbourhood and in the Western Balkans. At the Zaghreb EU—Western Balkans summit on 6 May, the leaders of the EU and Western Balkans partners agreed to reinforce their cooperation in addressing disinformation and other hybrid activities. As I said at the beginning, when fighting disinformation we must not forget the balance between the right of citizens to be properly informed and safeguarding the freedom of speech and the media. In the wake of the COVID—19 pandemic, unprecedented circumstances led many Member States to adopt far—reaching measures which were key to acting rapidly and effectively protecting the health of the citizens.  Many of these measures had a significant impact on fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law. It is therefore essential to make sure that they remain proportionate to the objective, limited in time and subject to regular scrutiny. The emergency measures taken to tackle the pandemic must not be used as a pretext to censor news and informal information coverage or to violate fundamental rights. It is critical that governments support the work of the independent media, which are crucial allies in the fight against COVID—19. The democratic debate, media freedom and the role of civil society deserves special attention. Upholding these values is a priority for the Council.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, it’s really evident that the virus pandemic has been accompanied by an ‘infodemic’, a pandemic of information. We have witnessed a wave of false and misleading information, and an exponential increase in targeted influence operations by foreign actors.  We have seen again that this information can do real damage. In the case of a pandemic, which affects the health of the people, it’s even more dangerous. We have seen disinformation saying that drinking bleach can cure the coronavirus. I’m not making any specific reference to anyone, but this has been said – drink bleach and you will be safe – or that washing hands doesn’t help. It can also spark crime. Take, for example, the vandalism against 5G infrastructure in some Member States, mainly in the Netherlands.  In March 2020, European leaders called on the Commission and the High Representative, through the External Action Service, to take action. Last week, we followed up with a joint communication on disinformation related to the pandemic. Together with my colleague and friend, the Vice—President in charge of Values, I will also comment on this communication. This communication summarises what the European Union has done to tackle disinformation in the crisis and how to step up action. Disinformation knows no borders. Democracies and the West as such have been the target of disinformation, which underlines the importance of international cooperation. Let me turn first to the external dimension. The infodemic has clearly been exploited by foreign state and non-state actors. Disinformation from Russian actors has spread conspiracy theories and orchestrated disinformation campaigns, targeting the EU and its Member States and neighbours by alleging a lack of solidarity and an internal crisis within the European Union, and sowing confusion. China has also participated in that. Russian sources are old news, but China has been more active. China’s sources have been promoting this image, presenting theirs as the better system, the best equipped to tackle the pandemic, and blaming democracy for its handling of the virus. One can imagine that doing self—praising propaganda is something that everybody does, but I think there are limits. It is one thing to explain that you believe yourself to be the best and another to deflect blame on the handling of the virus by others.  At the same time, there is a clear risk of governments using the infodemic as an excuse to limit fundamental rights and freedom of expression. Some Members referred to that in the previous debate. I think that the European Union needs to take a stand against this. What has been done to address these worrying trends? We have been working to promote strategic communication and public diplomacy in our neighbourhood, especially in the Western Balkans. The External Action Service has stepped up its efforts to address foreign influence operations, publishing regular reports, analysing the trends in disinformation and sharing findings with Member States, our international partners, civil society and the media. The people working at the External Action Service are doing extraordinary and difficult work in this field.  We have made good use of the instruments we have at hand to tackle disinformation overall in the current crisis. We have mobilised the Rapid Alert System, which connects all relevant EU institutions and all EU Member States. This has been proving to be a valuable network. Since the outbreak of the pandemic, a dedicated space has been set up to exchange information on disinformation related to the virus. We have further increased our cooperation with our international partners – NATO and the G7 and its Rapid Response Mechanism – and we are also happy to be working with valuable partners such as the United Nations and the World Health Organisation.  Looking ahead, we will step up our actions by enhancing concrete preparation on strategic communication and public diplomacy, increasing the sharing of best practice in fighting disinformation, and activating more quickly the Rapid Alert System, intensifying the joint work with relevant partners from civil society and the private sector, stepping up the monitoring of violations of press freedom and supporting advocacy for a safer media environment. On this, we now have a specific programme, under the Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace, to support regional governments in tackling the crisis and to debunk disinformation that can further fuel tensions in conflict areas.  I could go into more detail, but I think it’s now time to leave it to the Vice—President for Values and Transparency, Ms Věra Jourová, to continue on the important work with social media platforms and other aspects of this joint communication.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, we have just heard from Josep Borrell about the basic parameters and the information on what we call the ‘infodemic’ that is going on in parallel with the pandemic we are going through. This is why we decided to prepare the communication and adopt the communication, which has the title ‘Getting the Facts Right’. It was necessary because we needed to inform about what have been the steps taken up to now against disinformation because, in the COVID—19 context we didn’t start from scratch fighting against disinformation. We already had the Code of Practice and we had the Action Plan, and its second purpose was to come up with a to—do list for all involved, especially the platforms, to step up their work. In the communication we comprehensively address three things: the sources of disinformation, its channels and amplifiers, and also the targets. Josep talked about the foreign sources of disinformation and I am glad about this because I believe that a geopolitical EU can only materialise if we are assertive, but we also have to put our own house in order. We need to beef up our strategy on communication. We have to get our story out about Europe and EU support during the coronavirus crisis, and it is high time we step up on this and do not allow others to occupy that space. Now to the channels of communication and disinformation – especially the online platforms. I welcome the measures taken by them in this crisis; their strong commitment is heavily needed. I believe that the fact that we worked with the platforms, and we designed with them the code of practice on disinformation, helped to roll out new policies more quickly. We agreed with the platforms that they would promote links to the World Health Organization and health authorities and remove ads that offered fake medicines or inflate prices for normal products or give very dangerous advice, which we already heard from Joseph. These actions brought results. For example, Google blocked or removed globally over 80 million coronavirus—related ads. But there is room for improvement and our code was just a first step. We need to ensure transparency and accountability. Citizens need to know how information is reaching them and where it comes from. Our joint communication calls on the platforms to step up their efforts and to report monthly on their policies and actions to address COVID—19—related disinformation – not to report to the Commission, to report to the public, so that people can read about what’s happening online. The targets – well, it’s about us, it’s about the citizens of Europe. Lying is neither new nor that scary in itself. What scares me is that we believe in those lies too easily. This is why we need to become more resilient and critical as a society. We need to support free and independent media – the fact—checkers and researchers. And we have to step up our education. We will have the Digital Education Action Plan soon, adopted by the Commission, and there will be a very strong chapter on how to become more resilient and increase our critical thinking through education.  We will support fact-checking and research activities through the recently established European Digital Media Observatory. In this context, later this month, we will launch a EUR 9 million call for research hubs in the different Member States.  Also, we have to speak in this context about the freedom of speech, which remains our basic principle. Laws which define criminal penalties for spreading disinformation in too broad terms, and with disproportionate sanctions, can damage accountability mechanisms, which are just as important as ever. It can make the work of journalists more difficult, cause self—censorship and damage freedom of expression. This is not the European way. It is bad for democracies and it is self—defeating. Our best defence against disinformation are free and plural media, informed and active citizens and resilient democratic institutions in which they can trust.  I really want to insist on this because I believe this is a distinctive part of our policies. I do not want to create any Ministry of Truth. I used to live in a system, before 1989, with only one official truth, no pluralism of media, opinion, or even thought.  A competitive market of ideas enabled by free speech is essential in democracies. Just as in traditional competition policy where consumers benefit from fair competition and a level playing field, citizens benefit from fair competition of free speech. To conclude, the communication is the first building block of this new Commission in response to disinformation. We are working on the Digital Services Act and the European Democracy Action Plan where we will address illegal content and harmful content like disinformation.  In this context, I really appreciate that we can work on this together with the committee which you established in Parliament, because I believe that common work can bring good fruit.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the COVID-19 situation has only underscored that disinformation can kill people, just like it can kill democracy. We must therefore confront the spread of lies in our public space much more systematically. While I welcome the plans to step up EU efforts to counter disinformation, we need a tougher European action to fight off disinformation campaigns from Russia and China. We must speak with one, firm European voice against the actions by Russia and China, keen to undermine our European way of life. But the fight against disinformation is not a narrow matter of foreign policy. We need robust action towards social media platforms that help spread disinformation. I welcome the Commission proposal that platforms report monthly on COVID-19 disinformation, but we need to think beyond the current crisis and take clear and, yes, legislative action that ensures that all social media platforms behave responsibly and report transparently on their fight against disinformation. For the sake of the safety of our citizens, of all of us in Europe, we must protect facts from lies, science from hoaxes and journalists from facts and crooks, and we can only do this effectively together in the European Union.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the spread of disinformation and fake news is a direct threat to our societies. It undermines our democracies, it harms our values and it affects our interests. But during a pandemic, as the Minister said, disinformation puts lives at risk. But not even deadly consequences have stopped foreign actors from spreading fake news. The amount of influence, operations and misleading campaigns, mainly from China and Russia, has been massive. Interference and hybrid warfare should never be a strategy, but especially not during a global health crisis. The Commission’s communication is another important step towards a solid, comprehensive and effective strategy against foreign interference. We need tougher regulations. The EU has been targeted with unprecedented actions. They require a firm and unprecedented response. The S&D Group is at the forefront of this fight. At our initiative, today we will vote on the establishment of a special committee against foreign interference and disinformation. Urgent action is the only way to protect our democracies, and the European Parliament is ready to play that role.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the days when there was more malicious misinformation coincide with the time when the European institutions or Parliament had not yet reacted effectively and forcefully, or not with the utmost efficiency and forcefulness, to the pandemic. That vulnerability was what they exploited. Why? Because there is a strategy to weaken the democratic rule of law, our democratic systems, and the elements of vulnerability are those by which these strategies are introduced.  It seeks to have people addicted to lies, fanatical against which he thinks differently, acting as new soldiers on the new battlefield "on the Internet". And these fanatical groups polarize public space, weaken ideological pluralism, and thus weaken our democracies. That's the point.  Therefore, they shout more and frighten and we have to defend freedom of expression and a clean play space and fight against the pandemic of fanaticism that can undermine democracies. Soldiers who do misinformation don't know it, but geostrates who want to end our democratic systems, yes. And we're going to defend ourselves and, of course, we're going to win this.

name: Filip DE MAN
text: on behalf of the ID Group. Mr President, we are on a dangerous path. More and more governments are threatening a foundation of our Western democracy, free speech. The European Commissioners are also agitating, of course: there was an Action Plan against Disinformation, a Strategic Communication Task Force, a Rapid Alert System and even the private sector was called upon to act against disinformation. Fact-checkers need to fine-measure our information, and here too, of course, the saying goes: "whose bread one eats, his word one speaks" and those who do not believe it, may always outsource the appointments of the fact-checkers to me. Now all this, because the population is, of course, less and less at the hands of the traditional parties and the traditional media, and the regime is thus losing its grip on the spirits. So I say out loud: stop this covert censorship! Long live the diversity of opinions!

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, it should be clear to us there will never be a silver bullet to solve all problems of disinformation. But hey, we are in politics, and we all know there is rarely a one-size-fits-all approach. But we should be clear about our starting point, and the starting point is to defend our democracy, not to damage it. That’s why our strategy should be threefold and should be holistic. First, fight geopolitical propaganda attacks from outside. Second, educate and inform press and internet consumers. And third, protect personal opinion and free speech. The past weeks have demonstrated the pitfalls, but also the chances that we saw. There was a strong sense of direction from the European institutions, and I’m grateful to Mr Burrell for framing it right. It’s not about just fake news, it’s about a debate and a battle of narratives. On the other hand, we saw how we can end up in an anti-democratic trap. This is why criminalisation of alleged misinformation about COVID, like in Hungary, attempted prevention of true press information in Poland, prosecution of pharmaceutical representatives in Bulgaria – just because they wanted to warn about a lack of drugs. This is all unacceptable. We should not lose sight of our strategic principle. By confronting disinformation, we must defend democracy, not destroy it. And one more point, because many people represent it here. Anonymity is an important good in the internet. Anonymity protects women, minorities, opposition voices in the internet, and that’s why we should never abolish this there. One more point on education and then I’m done. We should invest more in education, in justice and value systems and not cut this by 20% as is planned now in the MFF, and we should invest more as part of the recovery in civil society and education and not disregard it as is planned now. This is the way to go. This is the way to protect democracy.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: ECR Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is experiencing an unprecedented crisis of credibility. Since Brexit's victory in 2016, some Member States and the Union institutions have attributed their own lack of credibility to disinformation campaigns by external or internal actors, but forget that misinformation does not come only from there and is also something new. The lie has always existed and has usually come from power. I would like to remind you that in the first pages of the Bible it is already told how the serpent deceives Adam and Eve to drive man out of paradise, defying God. But are we talking about misinformation or are we talking about censorship and ending freedom of expression? I am very concerned that the Commission will turn these data verification companies into the subjects who say what is true and what is a lie. And I am concerned that, on top of that, they will receive public aid, because they are only private companies in the service of their own political or economic interests. The coronavirus crisis has taught us that no one is foolproof. And here everyone has misinformed, starting with China, the World Health Organization, governments themselves and the media. Believing that truth is going to be fabricating in this Parliament is an act of unacceptable pride, like Adam and Eve's.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, High Representative, Madam Vice-President, it is obvious that during this period, in addition to the coronavirus crisis, we experienced this shock called the information pandemic, which must be said exactly as it happened because the truth must not be avoided in this situation.  The seat of this false information is in the Russian Federation. We in Romania, in the Baltic countries, in Poland, know that Russia specialises in distorting realities, and this attack, Vice-President Borrell, is an extremely harsh attack on European cohesion.  It's good what you said. We found that there are commitments; action is needed. The Russian Federation must receive a response commensurate with these misinformations. There are thousands of news stories that the Commission has presented as part of this disinformation plan, and we must act, including here in Parliament, through a resolution.

name: Marina KALJURAND
text: – Madam President, I would also like to thank the Council and the Commission for their statements, and I will continue in Estonian. Disinformation is not a new phenomenon, and yet every time we are hit by yet another wave of disinformation, it is about interference in democratic elections or attacks on individual Member States. I recognise that, during the corona crisis, which is a global crisis, the dissemination of false information has reached a new level, starting with information on the origin and spread of the coronavirus and ending with false medicines and charlatan treatments. And this wave is not over and will not end unless we stop wondering and not take action. I would argue that there is an idea and experience, but there is a lack of determination and speed. In today's debate, very true ideas were heard – exposing disinformation sources and sharing information based on facts, working with Member States, institutions and media platforms, responsibilities of the press and educating people. I welcome the initiative of the Commission and the External Action Service relating to the fight against disinformation related to the coronavirus. "Tackling coronavirus disinformation, getting the facts right" – I am pleased that it grew out of the Eastern Strategic Communication Task Force, which was launched five years ago by Estonia, Lithuania, Denmark and Great Britain. I repeat that we have the knowledge and experience to combat misinformation. It is time to decide and act, which in turn means resources – people and funds; and it is important to have information in all the official languages of the European Union, not just in some of the languages selected, as it is unfortunately now.

name: Bart GROOTHUIS
text: – Madam President, I very much welcome the extra steps that the Commission has taken, but I also think they’re somewhat cautious, preliminary, and I see them as first steps in a larger way that we can walk. I think there’s much more to be done, and I think the Renew fraction is coming with new proposals in the next coming months. I think the proof of the pudding in countering disinformation is in the eating. Now this week, a European NGO – EU DisinfoLab – actually meticulously disclosed a Russian state-sponsored disinformation operation inside Europe directed against Europe. So now, what do we do? Just imagine, dear Commissioners, if we would put the centre of gravity of this information operation on the EU sanction list, it would deprive them of hosting providers providing them with websites, it would deprive them of financial services, it would freeze assets of the people behind the information operations, and it would also restrict travel. So this is imposing costs on our adversaries. So if I look to the future of countering disinformation operations, I see it in this way. So please join us in the future, not just looking at the symptoms, but also at the root cause of it all.

name: Jean-Lin LACAPELLE
text: Madam President, the European Union is clearly not ashamed to dare to speak of the misinformation that would have existed on the part of private or foreign interests during the pandemic. She has among the members of her Council an expert in misinformation and untruths, in the person of Emmanuel Macron. He was the one who despised our group when we called, on the basis of the precautionary principle, for the closure of the borders as early as 24 January. His government replied: "The virus does not have a passport." It was he who, in order to hide the shortage of masks in France, explained that wearing masks was useless. What a tragedy, when we know that our elders were abandoned for lack of protective equipment and that the first mass order registered by the French government dates only from March 5. Finally, it is through the voice of his Minister of Health that he declares that testing massively is not useful either, hiding the shortage of tests. That's a lot of state lies on the part of those who should be exemplary. Lies that have had dramatic consequences and for which accountability will be held. So, ladies and gentlemen of the Council and the Commission, spare us your moral lessons on misinformation when you yourself are a sad example.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Disinformation, of course, is not a new phenomenon and did not start the day before yesterday, before the pandemic. It has existed for a long time. But now, due to advanced technologies and available methods, it has actually become very dangerous. We are discussing disinformation in Parliament today, and it was yesterday that the European Parliament rejected the request to waive the immunity of Guy Verhofstadt. Is this how the European Parliament fights disinformation? It is really clear from yesterday's speech that it is possible to sow lies and hatred in public, even in the European Parliament. This member of Parliament insulted thousands of Poles on our national holiday, saying that in Poland thousands of fascists and supporters of white supremacists marched three hundred kilometers from the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp. Ladies and see, this is proof that the European Parliament itself is becoming a source of disinformation and fake news. Since Poland has a painful history, please forgive my emotions, I am deeply moved.... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, masks are only important for the sick and health personnel, masks serve to protect themselves and others, there is no firm evidence of transmission from person to person, moderate risk, high risk, serious illness, not recommended to limit travel and travel, transmission from asymptomatic cases is rare, monitor asymptomatics, and I could go on. Which of these statements can be labelled as misinformation? The source is always the same, it is the WHO. During this pandemic, the bodies publicly considered to be reliable have said everything and the opposite of everything. Today we think of fake news only spread via the web, but we can also reflect on so-called official communication. There has been a lack of central management of the crisis and an attempt has been made to demonise my country, which, with courageous choices, fought against the virus first in Europe. Terrible! I have a proposal, Commissioners: let us help citizens to have instruments for critical analysis of sources and let us safeguard access to information and freedom of expression. We make projects like Media Literacy for all of programs stable, so that we always promote media literacy and information culture ..... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent months we have seen continuous disinformation on the issue of the Covid epidemic, we have seen all kinds of fake news circulating and we have seen an effort to put Europeans against each other, to ridicule Europe's commitment. We finally have an opportunity now, with this commitment from the European Parliament, to launch a special committee to combat disinformation and fake news. It will be approved in these days to combat those who want to divide Europeans, for interests that we know come from afar. We have seen in recent months, in recent years, journalistic investigations and judicial investigations that have investigated the circulation of money and support for a false right, the false right to the paid amplification of one's propaganda. We need to defend freedom of expression, but we also need to defend the freedom to know the sources and to defend our democracy, a fragile asset that must be defended by all the institutions.

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Thank you for your vote. I would also like to thank Vice-President Jurova for information on the European Commission's work in this area.  The pandemic of disinformation is now one of the greatest threats to democracy and the existence of the European Union. The coronavirus pandemic reminded us that reliable information can save lives, and fake news and hejt can kill.  Today, disinformation is gaining and maintaining power in many places around the world, including in the European Union. We are helpless witnesses to the annulment of democracy.  The power of the internet shows the power of the destruction of misinformation, which spreads faster than the virus. We must support true freedom of expression, but remember that freedom of expression used for disinformation is the antithesis of freedom. False elections will never be democratic. Freedom cannot be used for enslavement. We must be resistant to misinformation. We need to educate how to critically analyse the message from an early age. The remedy for disinformation must be increased media independence and pluralism, support for journalists and general access to reliable information.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Madam President, Mr High Representative, Madam Vice-President, we all know that a simple lie that reassures us is better than a complicated and disturbing truth. And it is in this world that we live now, with social networks that amplify, that allow us to go much faster on this misinformation, on these lies. We do have to fight these practices, as you both said, and you have said that very well. As you said, Mrs Jourova, and we know that you come from a world that has been totalitarian, you come from a world where censorship has ruled people's lives. We must not fall into this world and that is the first pitfall.  But I draw your attention and draw the Commission's attention to a second pitfall: we must also be careful. Let us not be naïve, we know that foreign powers are attacking us, we also know that they have relays within our democracy and that illiberal democracies are developing there and that extremes are also carrying these lies. So let us be careful to make sure that we do not fall into censorship on the one hand and put on the clothes of our adversaries, but at the same time, let us not blindly trust the market. We have seen, and I will end on this, that for the same misinformation, and you have targeted it, Google will ban, Twitter will leave but explain and Facebook will totally leave freedom in the name of freedom of expression. So we can't trust the simple rules of the market either. We will regulate and we will be by your side. Thank you, High Representative, thank you Vice-President.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her "A person sees – and this is important: nothing is completely wrong and nothing is quite right." A quote from Eugen Roth – I would like to share this with you here. But a second thing I would like to say is a very massive case of disinformation. If the Commission and the Council are so committed, I would ask you to investigate this. This case is remarkable because this is a government of a Member State. Specifically, it is about the Austrian Federal Government, where, for example, at the beginning of this COVID crisis, the Chancellor said in a speech: 'Soon each of us will know someone who died of Corona'. This is a special announcement from a Chancellor who, of course, is spreading fear among his own people. The second case is that of Health Minister Anschober – who qualifies as health minister by being a teacher – who, by decree – which is now the famous Easter decree – has informed people that they are not allowed to meet with their families in private premises at Easter time. That, too, is not the truth. That was not included in that decree, and that decree did not give it up. I would therefore ask you to investigate these two massive disinformation in one Member State and to pursue this.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Disinformation is one of the strongest weapons in the modern arsenal of asymmetric warfare. It's a great way to build internal tension, chaos, fear in your opponent's country. Fake news feeds on ignorance, half-truth, lack of transparency, adequate information. What is important in all of this is the collapse of the press, the written press, but also the power of social media. Therefore, the best way to combat disinformation is through openness, verifiability of information and good cooperation – our good cooperation. So many truths, half-truths, lies, false information that have been made in Poland, hungary – which has never been checked, only repeated and repeated – this is disinformation. And then its effects are deply depeded for the European Union, for its image. Consultation, clear, efficient information together with a verifiability mechanism – these are the most important tools to combat disinformation. And this should not, above all, restrict the internet.

name: Javier ZARZALEJOS
text: – Madam President, one of the consequences of the digital revolution is that the media media's media role as independent filters of information quality has been dramatically reduced. Disinformation appears in this vacuum and is the gap that we have to fill, which raises the need to reconsider the responsibility of the platforms, the use of those technological tools that, with all the necessary precautions, can help the fight against fake news; and, of course, fact checking in terms of transparency and the role that all users must play. But it is also important that we look in our house because governments need a firm commitment to truthful, transparent and credible information. The high representative mentioned some outlandish and dangerous statements about the disinfectant power of bleach. Inventing reports from American universities and making up death tolls, with contempt for reality, is also an exercise in misinformation.

name: Alessandra BASSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the direction taken is not convincing. It is claimed that it does not want to compress freedom of expression but, at the same time, it wants to highlight information professionals and block the social accounts of those who spread fake news. I would point out that information professionals are often little more than propaganda bodies. We remember that in Italy they supported the position of the government and those who wanted to defeat Covid with an aperitif, instead giving the racist to those who asked for stricter measures. Under the pretext of defending health and combating fake news, you want to gag those who say uncomfortable things. Those who want to defend freedom of expression fight fake news with truth and not with censorship.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, for over four months we have been fighting an unprecedented pandemic that has changed our lives dramatically and forced us to adapt to a new normal. The virus has left a massive and devastating impact, but we have managed to stay united in solidarity. However, the COVID pandemic is not the only battle we are fighting. We are witnessing an enormous wave of disinformation about the coronavirus, aims at portraying us as ineffective and divided in our response. The disinformation campaigns are particularly strong in the Western Balkans, where they aim at destabilising the region and turning public opinion against the European Union. Although the European Union provided an unparalleled support of EUR 3.3 billion to the Western Balkans during the crisis, the polls still show that a majority of citizens think that other regional powers provided more. The best way to fight disinformation is with transparency, accountability and increased visibility. Therefore, I welcome the efforts of the East StratCom Task Force and the EU Rapid Alert System that fact check and share genuine information. But we, as representatives of European citizens, should also go the extra mile. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this very interesting and important debate. I am sure this is not the last time we debate about the power of the internet, and for a very good reason, because we see the power of it every day. We see that the internet can serve as a fantastic tool to organise humanitarian aid, but also the internet can be the place where some humanitarian disaster and real fight and violence can be incited. So I think that this is a very serious topic to discuss. We have only started, as I said before, because ahead of us is the work on the European Democracy Action Plan, where we will speak about a very serious issue: how to protect the elections against disinformation, how to stop something I call privatisation of public debate, because we see the phenomenon of the algorithms, which are used to sell products, but which are also used to sell politicians. We face the new factor of lying in the political debate, which has the potential to win elections. We will have to discuss all these very substantial but at the same time sensitive issues. So I look very much forward to the discussion. I look very much forward to cooperation with the committee which you have established, and I’m sure that by the end of this year we will not only see how we are fulfilling the tasks from the communication we speak about today, because there is a to-do list, but also that we are able to come to a good common solution on the issues I mentioned before.

name: n/a
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. "Thank you very much for this debate, which has certainly not exhausted the subject. There have been very important, interesting contributions. Some very original, such as referring the origins of misinformation to Adam and Eve. It had not occurred to me that Adam, deep down, was the victim of the misinformation propagated by Eve, who did not warn her of the consequences of eating the apple. Well, yes, it's possible that Eva was the victim of misinformation. But today, in our world, we must recognize something that I believe is at the basis of our debate. Democracy is a system that works on the basis of the information that citizens have. Citizens choose. And to choose, they need to be informed of the options presented to them and value the action of governments, and that requires freedom of information, plurality of information and truthfulness in information. If citizens get misinformation, they can't make good choices, because it's like a plane that has the wrong navigation system. He'll end up crashing. And so it is so important that we fight to ensure that information, understood as a public good, is available to citizens and citizens have verification systems that let them know if someone is telling them a milonga — in castizo, castizo Castilian — if anyone is lying to them. Because I do not believe — whatever the Austrian poet in question says - that there is a part of truth and a part of lies in everything. Not really. Look, there are things that are clearly true and other things that are clearly false. That 2 and 2 are 4 in the base system 10, that has nothing false, it is true one hundred percent. And there are things that are absolutely false, say it whoever says it. That there are elements of opinion in some information in which one may be for or against for reasons of taste, opinion, ideological inclination... right, of course. Others, there would be no political debate. But one thing is the proper assessment of the facts and another thing is the facts. And as my colleague has said, we do not intend to create the Ministry of Truth. She already had one in her country; I also had one, in Spain, when there was a Ministry of Information. No, we do not intend to create the ministry that controls what we may or may not know. We intend to help citizens to be able to distinguish truth from lies. And that's the basis of the democratic system. If we are not able to do that, our democracy will be profoundly imperfect and will not end up being so. And that is why this work, this task, is something that needs the support of democratic forces throughout the parliamentary arc to get democracy to survive.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members. This topic is a priority for our Presidency. It is our obligation to protect our citizens from disinformation, in full respect of fundamental rights such as the freedom of speech, the media and association. Our common values and democratic institutions are keystones to the resilience of our societies to the challenges of the Covid—19 pandemic. We will continue working horizontally across sectors and across borders, learning from each other through the exchange of information and best practices. We very much look forward to working with you, with the Commission and with the EEAS to fight this pandemic and protect our citizens from harmful disinformation. Upcoming initiatives like the European Democracy Action Plan and the Digital Services Act will enable us to step up our collective efforts.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: in writing. – Commission Vice-President Věra Jourová finally ‘named and shamed’ China, along with Russia, this week in the communication on ‘Tackling COVID-19 disinformation’ for engaging in ‘targeted influence operations and disinformation campaigns around COVID-19 in the EU, its neighbourhood and globally, seeking to undermine democratic debate and exacerbate social polarisation, and improve their own image in the COVID-19 context’. It is our duty to protect Europe and its citizens. It is our duty to tell the truth and to reveal the sources that intentionally cloud it or twist it to serve their own interests. It is our duty to ensure that the truth shines through on all occasions. I do hope the Commission continues in this direction and exhibits the same determination in other contexts such as Turkey’s shameless disinformation campaign about the situation at the Greek-Turkish border, where refugees and migrants are being used as pawns in Turkey’s geopolitical chess game at Europe’s external borders, as European leaders had the chance to see with their own eyes. After all, an affront to the truth is an affront to European values. It is an affront to democracy itself and it cannot be tolerated.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: in writing. – Recent times have been marked by a theme that leaves no one indifferent: COVID-19. COVID-19 shook the status quo. In addition to profound changes, there has been a phenomenon that has made it difficult for health authorities to act. An infodemia, denounced by the WHO, defined by an excess of information, which made it difficult to find reliable sources and guidelines. The excess of information, much of it not based on scientific evidence, makes it difficult for reliable sources to be quickly found by the general population, policy makers and health professionals when they need it. This excess of unscientific and often contradictory information can make people feel anxious, depressed, overwhelmed, emotionally exhausted and unable to intend and assimilate important information. Misinformation, as well as the assimilation of unvalidated information can lead to wrong or biased decision-making by the lack of scientific evidence. The development of a mechanism that controls the quality and veracity of what is published is urgently necessary, in order to ensure the greatest scientific evidence in decision-making processes, but also that credible information validated by the scientific process reaches all citizens.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. – During the COVID-19 pandemic there was a massive wave of false or misleading information, mainly disseminated on the web, including some attempts by foreign actors to influence citizens and public debates in the EU. Disinformation campaigns can pose a serious threat to citizens' fundamental rights, from the right to health to the right to be properly informed, and to democracy itself and the rule of law. There are many complexities that this challenge entails: distinguishing between illegal and harmful but not illegal content and calibrating the respective responses; to ensure a correct balance between the freedom to manifestation of thought and the right to correct information. To address them, we need to invest in communication, to make citizens aware and to equip them with critical thinking and digital skills; support the independence and freedom of the media, which are necessary to provide citizens with verifiable and reliable information and, in the context of the pandemic, to preserve their health; ensure transparency and accountability of digital platforms, whose contribution is essential in the fight against disinformation campaigns.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. – An unprecedented 'infodemia', characterized by a bombardment of information, often false, inaccurate and misleading, has accompanied the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic. Excessive information flow has often created an effect of confusion, fear, and sometimes generated unconscious mass behaviour, as we have seen with assaults on supermarkets and means of transport. In this context, there has been no shortage of hate speech, consumer fraud and cybercrime. The threat of misinformation has emerged mainly through the web, on social networks and personal messaging platforms, used massively in recent months for the fast sharing of mostly unverified news. There is also a clear risk that 'infodemia' and measures taken in emergency periods may be useful in restricting fundamental rights and freedom of expression. The challenges of disinformation at different levels must therefore be addressed, from monitoring and analysis of information flows to close cooperation between institutions and social platforms, from the protection of fundamental rights to greater public awareness, from a free and plural media system to the strengthening of democratic institutions in which everyone can place full trust.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union's response to the coronavirus crisis leaves much to be desired. Disinformation and obstruction of access to reliable information have also emerged in the information space around the pandemic. This shows the importance of building society's resilience to false narratives in the fight against disinformation.  In this context, it is worth alluding to historical policy and disinformation in this regard. In May this year, the Russian Rodin Party presented in the State Dummy of the Russian Federation a draft law annulling a resolution condemning the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact – "On the political and legal evaluation of the Soviet-German Non-Aggression Treaty of 1939" – adopted on 24 December 1989. This is not the first manifestation of Russia's attempt to shed its co-responsibility for World War II. One element of this narrative is to blame for the outbreak of World War II fighting Germany on all fronts Polish, which suffered the highest percentage of population losses (for every thousand inhabitants lost 220 people).  The EP should remain committed to opposing Russian attempts to falsich European history. It is therefore necessary to support the initiative of the Lithuanian MEP, Minister of the Juknevičienė Race, to set up a working group on European historical memory. The aim of the group's work should be to defend historical truth, to cultivate historical memory of the crimes of totalitarian regimes in Europe, both Nazi and communist.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The COVID-19 pandemic was accompanied by a global infodemic consisting of misleading health care information, conspiracy theories, consumer fraud, and targeted disinformation campaigns by countries like Russia and China. While disinformation campaigns are not a new phenomenon, this crisis has shown us that they are not only detrimental to democracy, but can be detrimental to people’s health. I commend the Commission for outlining concrete action steps on this matter – we need bolder and tougher action against disinformation. I would like to focus on the central role that online platforms and digitalisation play in response to disinformation. Online platforms have to do their part: promoting authoritative content from professionals, including tools and initiatives to inform their users of false content and continuing their cooperation with EU institutions and Member States. Digital skills – one of my main priorities – are key to empowering citizens and raising their awareness, information literacy, and critical thinking. When it comes to online platforms, we need to think beyond the current crisis and take legislative action that ensures their responsible behaviour in the future. It is imperative that we continue to tackle disinformation and propaganda while simultaneously maintaining the utmost respect for freedom of expression and democratic norms.

name: Dace MELBĀRDE
text: Writing. – A complex approach to combating disinformation at EU and Member State level, as also pointed out by the Commission. Combating disinformation must also be a priority objective of European foreign policy. Media literacy and critical thinking should be promoted to improve the resilience of society. Media literacy should be part of the standard of school education. At the same time, it is essential to work with all groups in society in cooperation with the media and public organisations, with a particular focus on seniors. I believe that media literacy should be given priority in the future Digital Education Action Plan. We need to strengthen editorially independent media and quality journalism. The pandemic has fuelled media awareness as part of critical democracy infrastructure, but at the same time exacerbated the market failures observed in the industry over the years, particularly sharply felt by the media operating in small markets, including local and regional ones. The EU needs to increase funding available to the media industry and address systemic issues of regulating online platforms. The Digital Services Act should oblige large internet platforms – gate keeper" to play an increasingly important role in the acquisition and circulation of information, to prioritise high-quality media and journalism content in the information stream. I call for a doubling of the creative Europe budget and for substantial funding for the news media to be increased. The EU must also introduce a digital tax as soon as possible and channel revenues to support the media industry. At the same time, I hope that the Member States will make effective use of the instruments provided for in the Recovery Plan, with adequate funding being invested in the news media as one of the most affected ecosystems.

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: in writing. – Dear colleagues, I listen to your speeches and think of a message Matthew attributes to Jesus Christ: "And why are you looking at the straw in your brother's eye and not paying attention to the beam in your eye?" For years, the European Union has been debating whether and what measures to take, against whom, how serious. Coronavirus doesn't change anything, it's just another crisis that's being used for political capital. However, the big problem is the inclination of some of you towards totalitarian measures in your own countries. The serious threat does not come from the outside, but from the inside, because some governments have decided to manipulate the information that their citizens have access to. Democrats allegedly repealed transparency laws and canceled parliamentary scrutiny sessions. And no, I am not talking about your "favorite" Hungary and Poland, where governments act with the full support of citizens, but about Spain, Italy, Sweden. Colleagues, you protect left-wing governments in these countries and cover up their disinformation campaigns, but you're going to get hurt. When you turn disinformation into government policy, your own citizens will put you in place. Thanks for the attention.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on the brief presentations – the report by Petras Austreviius on the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council, the Commission and the Vice-Presidents of the Commission and high representatives of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Eastern Partnership in the run-up to the Summit in June 2020 (2019/2209(INI)) (A9-0112/2020) and – the report by Tonino Picula on the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council, the Commission and the Vice-Presidents of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the countries of the Western Balkans following the 2020 Summit (2019/2210(INI)) (A9-0091/2020). I would like to point out once again that there are no spontaneous speeches and no blue cards in this debate. We have a correspondingly shortened debate.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and colleagues who constructively contributed to this report. The Eastern Partnership is about closer association between the European Union and six partner countries. The extent of these relations and positive results of the European Union’s support and action in its immediate neighbourhood will determine the Union’s odds of global leadership. Leadership requires a strong commitment. Such commitment should be demonstrated by passing a historically justified and politically endorsed message to our partners that ‘their European aspirations are recognised and that by working together we can achieve necessary reform progress’. It is only a matter of time.  Our motto for the next decade of the Eastern Partnership should be ‘more for more’ and lead towards gradual and differentiated integration. It should be conditioned on the application of European values and democratic principles.  I very much regret that Mr Borrell is leaving the Chamber, although CommissionerVárhelyi is here. I have a very personal message for him as well.  In the political area, our partners require continuous support and guidance in strengthening their democracies, ensuring the rule of law and fighting corruption. As in the economic field, we should gradually open access to the EU single market by creating a common economic area. Let us remind ourselves that European security is indivisible. We cannot look at it through the Eastern or Western dimensions. There is only one, European, dimension and it is time to act as such. The Eastern Partnership initiative is rightly called a success story and will remain such as long as we act together, united by a common vision and joint action, dialogue and partnership.   Commissioner Várhelyi, as you know from today’s news from the prison in Belarus, the leader of the Christian Democratic Party has cut his veins in protest at violence and injustice. I request from you a strong message and reaction to this inhuman act.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I am pleased to speak here today about the future enlargement and its importance for the future of the European Union, but I want to thank shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation and dedication in our common endeavour. The main message of this report is to once again provide strong support of the European Parliament in the continuation of the enlargement process as one of the European Union’s more successful and strategic policies. Enlargement is our most effective foreign policy instrument contributing to extending the outreach of the Union’s core values, fostering peace and prosperity, equality, rule of law and respect for human rights across Europe. This report highlights what is often forgotten: the merit-based prospect of full EU membership for the Western Balkans countries is in the Union’s own political security and economic interests, as well as it is in the interest of the countries seeking full membership. For the first time after the accession of Croatia in 2013, enlargement policy is again on the political agenda of the institutions. We welcome a new enhanced methodology breakthrough with the council’s approval to start negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania on the Zagreb Summit Declaration. Now we need the implementation of those decisions and proposals in concrete form and dates for starting accession negotiations. We would like to see a faster pace of closing chapters for the countries already negotiating, following more efficient scrutiny and supervision of their progress. It goes without saying that ambitious enlargement policy requires an adequate budget. Therefore the Council should provide for sufficient budgetary means in support of the enlargement policy. On the parliamentary role of cooperation, the European Parliament is committed to intensifying political and institutional support for reforms in the Western Balkan countries in the process of EU accession. Lastly, enlargement is a necessary condition for the EU’s credibility and influence in the region and beyond. We can only be successful globally if we are credible in our immediate neighbourhood.

name: Olivér Várhelyi
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, for our geopolitical Commission, full engagement with our neighbours is a top priority. These are not just words: we have translated them into action. Let me start with the Western Balkans, a region at the heart of Europe and surrounded by our Member States. In the first six months of our mandate we have first, in February, proposed a revised enlargement methodology. The aim was to make the accession negotiations more credible, more predictable, more dynamic and guided by a stronger political steer. Second, and despite the COVID pandemic, in March the Council adopted a decision to open accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania, and I’m pleased that both these decisions have been confirmed by the European Council. To support the region hit by the pandemic, in April, the Commission put forward an unparalleled financial package of EUR 3.3 billion, mobilised together with the European Investment Bank. In addition, we associated the Western Balkans to a number of initiatives normally reserved for our Member States only. In May, we had the Zagreb Summit, where EU leaders not only reiterated our strong solidarity with the region but also reaffirmed the region’s European perspective and sent a message of enhanced engagement from the EU side. The Commission was tasked to come forward with a substantial economic development and investment plan to accelerate the reforms and the catching-up of the region. Still this week, the Commission will propose the draft negotiating frameworks for Albania and North Macedonia to the Council, together with an update on the progress made. We look forward to the adoption and the first intergovernmental conferences soon. Enlargement is merit-based. To progress on their EU path, the Western Balkan countries need to continue to deliver on the reforms. Further work is required on the rule of law, the fight against corruption and organised crime, as well as on fundamental freedoms and human rights. Fast and tangible results on reform mean moving faster in accession negotiations, as was underlined in the enhanced methodology. The Commission will look at the progress achieved in the annual package to be presented in the autumn. Also in the autumn, we will come forward with an economic and investment plan for the Western Balkans to support the long-term economic recovery and to bring the region closer to the EU. The plan will reflect many areas identified in your report, such as connectivity (especially in transport and energy), green transition and digital transformation. This plan should bring growth and jobs to the region, also as part of our common recovery effort after the pandemic. Let me now focus on the eastern neighbourhood. Let me thank this House for your overall support for the vision on the future of the Eastern Partnership that we have put forward with the joint communication adopted in March. Our commitment towards the Eastern Partnership and its future was emphasised at last week’s Foreign Affairs Ministerial Conference, together with our partner countries. I am convinced that it will also be confirmed at the leaders meeting later this afternoon. Our aim is to build, together with the partner countries, an ambitious, flexible and inclusive partnership that constitutes and continues to bring concrete results to the people. In this context, I am proud that the EU is delivering close to EUR 2.5 billion in support for our eastern partners in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition to grants, this includes very substantial macrofinancial assistance in loans on highly favourable terms to help the countries cover their immediate urgent financing needs and strengthen their macroeconomic stability. This package also helps to save jobs as part of the economic recovery in the region by providing liquidity to the whole of the economy and by direct financial support to the SMEs. This crisis has further underlined how important resilience is as the overarching framework for our relations, and it will be at the heart of the Eastern Partnership going forward. Our March communication puts forward an ambitious vision for our future cooperation through five broad policy objectives. First, to work towards resilient economies with strengthened connectivity. Second, to support the development of accountable institutions, the rule of law and security. Third, to support the green transformation and work on environmental and climate resilience. Fourth, support the digital transformation; and fifth, to work together towards the development of resilient, fair and inclusive societies. As a next step, we will work on transforming the policy objectives into practice. Together with the Member States, partner countries and others, we will shape the post 2020 deliverables, to be endorsed at the next summit in early 2021. We count on your continuous support and cooperation to ensure a strong partnership for the years to come. Finally, to the rapporteur, Mr Auštrevičius, I will look into this issue you mentioned. This is new to me. I was not aware of it and, of course, we will come out and make public messaging appropriately about it.

name: Nicola BEER
text: That concludes this item. The vote on the report by Mr Austreviius will take place on Friday, 19 June 2020. As far as Mr Picula's report is concerned, the vote on the amendments will take place today, 18 June 2020, and the final vote will take place on Friday 19 June 2020. name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. As the European Union leans at the bedside of Albania or Kosovo, opening negotiations with one and considering visa exemption for the other, what a dismaying spectacle that of a Kosovar President dismissing the representative of the Union and appointing Washington as the only legitimate interlocutor for the talks with Serbia. Further proof that the European Union is struggling to convert its considerable financial support, estimated at several billion euros, into political dividends, in the Balkans, which have become the playground of all the major world powers - from China to Turkey. As a sign of the times, these candidate countries do little to ignore the European accession criteria. What about Albania and its liberticidal laws, for example, causing its own President to fear that it will become the "North Korea of Europe"? Clearly, this umpteenth enlargement is a market of dupes, which will benefit only a few investors on the lookout for the lowest wage, in defiance of the interests of the peoples.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – The Eastern Partnership is of paramount importance to the EU and therefore it is necessary to convey ambitious messages that represent a realistic European perspective and involve mutual obligations. As for the reform processes of the KP countries, it is important to maintain the incentive for each country to close its relations with the European Union on the basis of its own ambition. It is important to recognise the aspirations of the associated members, but at the same time to strive for the unity of the Eastern Partnership and to make full use of the opportunities arising from the Association Agreement and the DEEP and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement. I think it is important that the infrastructure plan between the EU and the Eastern Partnership countries should include the expansion of border crossings in order to open up more new and modern border crossings between the EU and its neighbours.  We need to put more emphasis on young people, extend individual EU programmes to eastern partner countries, such as Erasmus+ and Creative Europe, which have already been implemented, and encourage participation in Horizon Europe. Eastern partner countries should be made aware of the need to create equal opportunities to represent all ethnic and national minorities when aliasing their electoral legislation, to ensure the right to information and expression in the mother tongue, to combat all forms of hate speech and discrimination on the basis of ethnic and linguistic grounds, to combat fake news and disinformation aimed at ethnic and national minorities.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - The Eastern Partnership is an essential part of the EU's neighbourhood policy and aims to achieve political association, ensure further economic integration, promote prosperity and provide a platform for solving common challenges, including the sustainable development challenge. It is important to give assurances to Georgia, Ukraine and Moldova that, despite the difficulties faced by the EU countries themselves, cooperation with the Eastern Partnership countries has not been left behind.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on: - the question with request for an oral reply to the Council on the situation in the Schengen area following the Covid-19 pandemic, by Juan Fernando López Aguilar, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000037/2020 - B9-0010/20), - the question with request for an oral reply to the Commission on the situation in the Schengen area following the Covid-19 pandemic, by Juan Fernando López Aguilar, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000038/2020 - B9-0011/20).

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner Johansson, as Chairman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, it is an honour for me to hold an oral question in this House to the Commission on Schengen.  We need to talk about Schengen. For starters because it's his birthday. On 14 June 1985, an agreement took place in a small town in Luxembourg, then continued under the 1990 Convention and in part by the European Schengen legislation adopted by this European Parliament and which is in force.  But we must talk about Schengen especially because it does not show good health. Because Schengen is at stake. And here's the thing. Those of us working in the European institutions often find it difficult to explain the 'European words', but Schengen needs no explanation. Because everyone knows that it is the most precious asset of the European experience. The asset that best distinguishes the advantages of being European. European construction. An area of free movement, without internal borders, without restrictions and without discrimination between Europeans, which is now enjoyed by more than four hundred million citizens of the European Union.  It turns out that the Schengen area is governed by European law: a Schengen Borders Code, a regulation which is directly binding on the Member States and invoking the courts in defence of European citizenship.  And it provides for conditions for the restoration of internal borders for public security reasons. But we have encountered an unprecedented situation: COVID-19. That is why the resolution following this oral question is precisely entitled 'Schengen area following the Covid—19 outbreak'. What about Schengen after COVID-19? Because the Member States have rushed to adopt unilateral, uncoordinated or interconnected measures to restore internal borders in the Union, which have produced very long queues at the Union's internal borders, caused police overload, caused problems in the supply of essential goods and also for seasonal workers, also protected by European law. We need to talk about all these problems in this oral question and that is why we have made it clear to you, first of all, whether you consider that the measures and restrictions that have been brought are respectful of the Schengen Borders Code, which lays down three principles: mutual trust, solidarity, but also the requirement of respect for law. And it is true that public security has been invoked more than once for the restoration of internal borders, especially after terrorist attacks. We've seen it. But public health has never been. It is covered by the Schengen Borders Code for the restoration of the Union's external borders, but not for the interiors; therefore, it is a lesson that we have to learn. Secondly, how does Schengen recovery envisage? We're talking about the recovery plan. How to recover Schengen to be fully operational as soon as possible?  Thirdly, how can we ensure that controls are exceptional, as the Schengen Borders Code wants, and in any case time-limited, time framed, with strict temporary restrictions? Fourthly, what practical measures can we take to ensure coordination and accountability, coordinated, of course, by the Commission — guardian of the Treaties and European law — in the face of common challenges.  I ask for a vote in favour of the resolution resulting from this oral question by, of course, thanking the work of the Schengen Scrutiny Group, represented here by its President Tanja Fajon, but I recall that, first of all, the content of the Resolution is a message to the Commission so that improvisation, uncoordination, decisions, and decisions will never take place , nor unilateral measures; that there is no dynamic or spiral of action-reaction of one State against another, let alone retaliations, based (inaudible words) on mutual trust, solidarity and coordination and respect for law. We are working for the health of the Schengen area. And finally, let me say that I am aware that this House (inaudible words) has enemies within the European Parliament, as it has (inaudible words), which take advantage of any situation for (inaudible words) the restoration of the Internal Borders of the Union. It should be noted that the majority of Parliament is committed to the Schengen recovery plan. He said it is essential to bet on a Schengen recovery plan to restore its health based on the principles of solidarity, mutual trust and non-discrimination between Europeans under no circumstances. Yesterday we debated racism here. The motto was "Black lives matter". Sure they do, and this gives me the right to say: "Schengen matters, too", "Schengen matters".  Black lives matter. Sure they do. (continues in English) Schengen matters too. (English) European law matters. European law matters even in times of crisis, even throughout the crisis. It must leave European law even throughout the crisis and learn out of experience. I would even add: European law matters especially in times of crisis, especially in times of COVID. (Spanish) full recovery (Spanish) That is why, after this oral question, we conclude with a resolution that bets on the full recovery of Schengen, the full restoration of its good health. The most precious asset of European construction ever.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, over the last few months, the European Union has been faced with the most challenging crisis since its creation. In addition to a very heavy toll on human lives, the COVID—19 pandemic has jeopardised certain fundamental elements of the European project, such as the internal market and the freedom of movement. I believe you would all agree with me that throughout this most critical period the absolute priority has, understandably, been to slow down and eventually stop the very rapid spreading of the virus. To that effect, many Member States have been forced to take legislative and practical measures which had a significant impact on free movement. In this context, the reintroduction of internal border controls was considered indispensable, even by some Member States which before the COVID—19 pandemic had been highly sceptical towards the application of such measures.  According to the Schengen Border Code, the reintroduction and prolongation of temporary internal border controls as a last resort and in response to a serious threat to public health can take place at the discretion of the Member States. Their application is, of course, subject to the fulfilment of the conditions set out in the relevant provisions. Neither the Commission, as the guardian of the Treaties, nor any Member State, has signalled any issue related to compliance with these conditions. Furthermore, I would like to stress that since the outbreak of the pandemic all Member States have been working tirelessly, with the political steering of the Council and the coordinating support of the Commission, in order to mitigate the side—effects of the measures imposed on the free movement of their citizens.  A series of Commission communications have been implemented by the Member States by way of priority to ensure the free flow of essential goods such as food, medicine and personal protection items, as well as the transfer of key cross—border workers and the repatriation of EU citizens and residents. At the same time, Member States have applied, in a coordinated way, restrictions on any unnecessary travel towards the EU.  At the second stage, as the overall health situation has started to improve, Member States have started easing the measures and full restoration of free movement within the European Union. This phasing—out entails, in some cases, a gradual approach and the replacement of internal border controls with alternative measures such as police controls within the territory. At any rate, Member States, with the support of the Commission, are strongly committed to applying any measures still temporarily needed, in full compliance with the principles of proportionality and non—discrimination. Most Member States and Schengen associate countries lifted internal border controls and related travel restrictions by mid-June. The rest intend to follow suit by the end of the month.  We are aware that there are still many steps to be taken, especially regarding the coherent lifting of external border restrictions. The fact that the lifting of internal border control in a coordinated way has been set in motion without major problems provides ample evidence of the Member States’ strong will for a fully—functioning Schengen area. I am hopeful that we can use this positive momentum, along with the possible proposals that we expect from the Commission regarding the legal framework for internal border controls, to launch a fruitful debate between the two co—legislators on this crucial subject, to safeguard the Schengen area. Any future amendments to the regime governing internal border control need to be stipulated in such a way as to provide credible answers to threats to public order, internal security and public health.
