They should ensure the strictly necessary and proportionate flexibility for Member States and leave no scope for any abuse in their application.

name: Ylva Johansson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Schengen is one of the major achievements and very much appreciated by our citizens, as was very rightly stressed by Mr Fernando López Aguilar, Chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE). I would also say that Schengen has passed not only a celebration of 35 years, but has also just passed a major test. At no time was Schengen more important than in the last few months. All Member States took drastic measures to protect our citizens from the virus. Most Schengen countries introduced temporary internal border controls in addition to other measures restricting free movement across the European Union. Altogether, these measures helped to save tens of thousands of lives but had serious consequences for freedom of movement and a large social and economic cost. On 5 April this year, the President of the European Commission and the President of the European Council presented a joint European roadmap towards lifting COVID—19 containment measures. In line with the principles established in this roadmap, the Commission presented, on 13 May, a communication setting out a coordinated, balanced and phased approach for lifting travel restrictions and controls at the internal borders. In the second stage, this also looked ahead to the ending of restrictions on non—essential travel to the EU through the external borders. Due to the improvement of the epidemiological situation, by this Monday most Member States had lifted internal border controls and restrictions, including post—travel quarantine requirements. The Commission has strongly encouraged the remaining Member States also to lift internal border controls and restrictions to free movement by air, land and water within the European Union at the same time. I expect that all internal border checks will have been lifted by the end of June before we start relaxing the external border restrictions. The Schengen rules provide Member States with a certain discretion to reintroduce border controls for two or six months at specific border sections or at all their internal borders. Member States should set up specific authorised border crossing points. Through bilateral contacts with Ministers and my regular video conferences with all the Schengen Ministers, based on the work at technical level of the COVID—19 information group (Home Affairs), we could address many issues and solve many problems, also regarding the scope of reintroduced border controls. In this emergency related to COVID—19, the Commission is of the opinion that EU Member States and Schengen states complied with the requirements of the Schengen Borders Code. Since 2015, six Schengen states have also reintroduced border controls under the Schengen Borders Code, following the recommendation of the Council, motivated by extraordinary irregular migration, secondary movements, the external border situation and terrorist threats. These controls have been prolonged and prolonged and prolonged until the end of October / mid—November this year. The Commission consistently encouraged alternatives to border controls, which may assure similar results. This concerns police checks, which, as explained in the recommendation of 12 May 2017 on proportionate police checks, can also be carried out in the border area and as such can replace non—systematic border checks. In 2017, the Commission also proposed an amendment to the Schengen governance rules with substantial reinforcement of procedural safeguards to ensure that the reintroduction of border controls is truly only a last-resort measure. As you know, the negotiations on these proposals are blocked, but recent experience with the use of border controls to address public health threats deserves further reflection. The Commission is committed to lead a process of reflection about the legal and practical steps needed to improve our response and better prepare our societies for similar emergencies. In particular, we have to be able to provide, in the case of pandemics, a coherent EU response at the internal and external borders. Currently, the EU can only intervene in the case of serious persistent threats at external borders, putting the overall functioning of the Schengen area at risk. COVID shows the need for better anticipation and for simplified or standardised procedures to be followed under the pressure of events. Decisions on the temporary reintroduction of border controls should be subject to consultation, including, where appropriate, joint meetings between the Member State concerned and the Commission. As the experience of recent months has shown, this provision of the Schengen Borders Code is rarely used in an emergency situation. The new pact on migration and asylum that I will present soon will be the occasion to launch a process to restore trust between Member States and return to a fully-functioning Schengen area. We will reflect on how to ensure coordination among the Member States during emergencies in the future and on the future of Schengen and how to make sure its legal framework and implementation are ready for new challenges.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, Schengen is undoubtedly one of the pillars of the European Union. I think perhaps that even the most important asset of European construction and there is no doubt that it has been called into question by this pandemic, it has been challenged as never before throughout our existence as a Union. Member States panicked and to protect their citizens reacted understandably with the unilateral and uncoordinated closure of borders.  Now we must ensure that there is a breakthrough for Schengen, a Schengen recovery, made with respect for the idea of coordination and articulation, and so I want to congratulate the Commission and thank the Commission for the effort it has made and which, unfortunately, I must say to the Council, the Member States have not always followed to coordinate and articulate the replacement of the Schengen area throughout the Union. It has been a huge effort that has not always been monitored by the Member States.  That is what Parliament supports here.  And now let me only stress one point – even to my President Lopez Aguilar – because it's not true that the Schengen Borders Code doesn't allow public health, because a serious threat to public policy includes public health in a pandemic and/or epidemic outbreak. Public health for external borders is independent of any epidemic or pandemic, and so I think that it is totally legal to have this situation that we have.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Mr President, Honourable Commissioner. First of all, a sincere thank you for all the cooperation and meetings of the last few weeks. I know that you are aware of the importance of restoring Schengen, because without the renewal of schengen, colleagues, there will be no reconstruction of the European economy. We're at a critical moment. Schengen is celebrating this year, this week, 35 years and has never been as seriously threatened as it is today. In the health crisis, it emerged that the outbreak of the epidemic, that countries reacted very egotistically, that there was no harmonisation, there was no concerted action, that most of them closed borders, that there was no movement of people, people could not return home, there was no supply of medical equipment and medical staff. We were not prepared for this situation and we need clear rules to avoid this. You yourself mentioned schengen has long been a serious test. For four years, six countries have been introducing internal controls without legal basis and without any real arguments. These border closures, these behaviours by governments and these actions by these countries call into question the whole of Schengen and the whole European integration project. And I wonder whether the measures were really justified. In Slovenia, Nova Gorica, man would be much easier to go to Stare Gorica, an Italian Mountain than maybe 100 km away in Maribor. We must also ask ourselves whether the measures were proportionate and effective. And I would very much like to remind you, colleagues, when we talk about a common migration and asylum policy, if we link this issue to the issue of Schengen action and reform, we will lose the project. Both packages of legislation, both migration and asylum policy and schengen reform, both packages of legislation have been adopted in this building and responsibility lies with the countries of the European Union.

name: Dragoş TUDORACHE
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, in the last plenary session I honoured Robert Schuman. His visionary statement anticipated a Europe that would integrate the project with the project, day by day, on the basis of mutual trust and solidarity.  Thirty-five years later, five Member States were taking such a small step, based on the confidence that they could leave their borders in the care of others. We add another thirty-five years and we come to what Schengen represents today: a fundamental freedom of European citizens, one that we have a duty to defend and strengthen. The pandemic has put the Schengen area to the test. We all felt the bitter taste of a Europe with borders and restrictions. The lack of coordination between the Member States, the too timid language of the European Commission and the closed borders have led European citizens to question our entire construction. We can't afford this to happen again.  This crisis has exposed us to many vulnerabilities, but it has also taught us a lot about ourselves, as citizens, as societies and as the Union. We have learned that we need each other, that we must support each other in difficult times, and that our resilience, that of Europe, depends on the resilience of all. We have all been outside the Schengen area for a few months and we have all understood what this means, which leaves us with a question: what about Romanian and Bulgarian citizens, for whom being outside Schengen is a daily reality that has been going on for thirteen years? We are all European citizens, and Romania and Bulgaria deserve a political message about what Europe means to all. I call on the German Presidency of the Council, which will take office in two weeks, to put the correction of this political anomaly on the Council's agenda.

name: Annalisa TARDINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is important for us to remember that the Member States retain sovereignty over the management of their borders, but we have been among the first, since the outbreak of the pandemic, to call for travel restrictions. Instead, the Commission, we have Commissioner Johansson here today, has criticised the reintroduction of internal border controls and has tried to delay restrictions at the external borders, closing them only when the spread of the disease was already out of control in several countries. If he had listened to us, we could have drastically reduced the spread of the pandemic in Europe and avoided the invasion, especially that of Sicily, resulting from the exponential increase in the landings of illegal immigrants, as if it had not been enough to welcome the torturers who arrived with racketeering.  We now hope, at least, that you will be able to show attention to certain key sectors of the European economy, such as tourism, transport and hospitality services, which have suffered serious damage and need to be encouraged. And on this I am sorry to note any words from the other groups.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, in March, Member States had to take, all of a sudden, a lot of measures in order to combat the spread of the COVID—19 virus. Among a lot of other measures, they closed their borders. This reflex to protect citizens is completely understandable, but it does not fit in an area where we have freedom of movement, where we have fundamental rights and where we have the principle of non—discrimination. As a result of the closing of the borders, EU nationals couldn’t return to their homes, couldn’t visit their family and couldn’t go to their jobs if they were frontier workers. We call upon the Member States, in new waves of viruses, to take real effective measures focusing more on health measures, and proportionate measures, and to make sure that they coordinate, especially in border regions. Although the internal borders are largely open now, the external border is still closed, and there we still see asylum seekers having practical problems in getting access to protection and family members in reuniting with their families in the EU. We call upon the Council and the Commission to really combat these violations.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this crisis has made clear the hijacking of the idea of Europe conceived years ago, the lack of scientific coordination in dealing with the health emergency, the lack of economic solidarity that we will see better in the coming days, the reversal of the Schengen principle that we are talking about today. In a disorderly manner, the freedom of movement of persons and goods in Europe has been this, while it has been claimed to open Europe's doors to immigration from outside Europe. Three days ago, in the LIBE Committee, we even paid tribute to one of the NGO ships that landed hundreds of migrants in Italy, while the Italians in those days died in their hundreds every day. None of this is Europe. I'm sorry, I don't know his name, but that's all.

name: Clare DALY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I think at this stage, for me, the Schengen acquis can be summed up as ‘free movement is a cherished European value, except when it isn’t’, which is quite a lot, especially if you’re a person of colour or someone who is black. I think we have to start by acknowledging that Schengen has been at breaking point since 2015. Internal border controls, which are only ever supposed to be allowed on a temporary basis as a measure of last resort, are being thrown up by Member States as and when they like: reintroduced and prolonged 50 times since 2015. At this stage, totally illegal, but the Commission has not acted to sanction these states. Of course you haven’t, when we’re talking about countries like Germany in April this year extending border controls with Austria under the threat of migration. I don’t how the migrants are going to make it through the Croatian borderguards beating them back there to make it to Austria in the first place. So in the context of the Commission failing to act, I’m really proud of the resolution that Parliament has on pushing back the attacks on Schengen. It’s the result of collaboration between the groups. We need to defend free movement and I hope the resolution is passed.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, respected colleagues, equality, multilingualism and common borders are one of the cornerstones of the European Union. We must not allow the declared Covid-19 pandemic to continue to maintain the bizarre situation in which four non-EU countries are in the Schengen area, while four countries: Romania, Bulgaria, Malta and Croatia, which have been together for 50 years in the European Union, are outside the area. I call on you all to do everything we can to ensure that all four states enter the Schengen area this year and not to allow the closure of borders that we have witnessed recently, where individual states have put and exercised border control because this is a blow to one of the pillars of the European Union, which are common borders, common space and unity among all citizens of the European Union.

name: Ioan-Rareş BOGDAN
text: – Mr President, Your Excellency, welcoming Romania into the Schengen area is not a fad. I note with sadness that almost Romania's only link with the Schengen area is that it provides seasonal workers. They do not benefit from the standard of health and safety in the Member State where they work, but that is what we will debate immediately. It is inadmissible to block Romania's entry into the Schengen area, even though it has met the technical criteria for accession since 2011. However, it is held at the door, although it is a provider of Euro-optimism. We are debating a functioning Schengen area today, but we refuse to strengthen it, and that is because states like the Netherlands, headed by its prime minister, have been unduly opposed for years by Romania's entry into Schengen. By the way, I invite Mr Mark Rutte to check the port of Rotterdam on cigarette trafficking and tax evasion.  Romania has a pro-European president and EPP government that is a strong supporter of the rule of law. I wonder: why are Romanians still being punished, even though they are the most pro-Europeans in the European Union?

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the 35 years of Schengen – an incredible success story!  And it is precisely the actions of the Member States under Corona – with many border closures – that have shown, as if under a burning glass, that Schengen is not self-evident, but it is urgently needed. Open borders in Europe are essential in the exchange of goods, services and medical aid, but there is much more at stake. The daily walk across a border, living and working or studying in two countries, cross-border leisure activities, daily coexistence across borders: this is the building block for understanding, despite or precisely because of many differences. That is why I urge the Commission and the Council – and, of course, the Member States – to strengthen and expand the Schengen area and let us live Europe together every day!

name: Fabienne KELLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, dear Ylva Johansson, at the beginning of the COVID crisis in mid-March, Europe has fragmented. Most Member States have reinstalled border controls. Thousands of citizens, border workers and families have been stranded and separated. I have seen this as a resident of a town on the border: Strasbourg. We must learn all the lessons from these unprecedented events. I propose to organize before this summer a RETEX, as the military says, that is, a feedback to analyze what happened, to see what could have been done better. We need to provide operational responses. I, like many of my colleagues, advocate for a more integrated mechanism for managing our borders. I suggest that you be prepared to deal with any new threats to free movement, especially in the event of a rebound in the epidemic. Free movement is a key factor in reviving the economy and jobs, as President Lopez Aguilar has pointed out.

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the These are difficult times in which we are living, and perhaps it is very important, especially in these difficult times, to realise once again what happiness it is that we can live in this Europe in these times. Let us imagine that we were born 100 years ago: the First World War would have just been two years over, the Spanish flu would have caused 50 million deaths, our childhood would have been marked by the great depression, and when we are 13, the Nazis will come to power in Germany. Until we are 25, the Nazis have led Germany and the whole world to the abyss. If you were as old as I am now, 32, it would have been another nine years before the Berlin Wall was built and an Iron Curtain cut through Europe. I believe that we should also place this happiness of not being born 100 years ago in a responsibility, especially in times of crisis, especially in times of crisis, especially in the case of such a virus, where we say: we are aware of what we have achieved, what achievements we have, and we now want to find targeted effective measures to harm the virus, not so much to the European project. , as has unfortunately happened in this crisis.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would immediately like to correct those of you who claimed that national governments were wrong in their response. No, dear, the European Commission was wrong. In particular, the European Commission has failed on the ˶ security at its borders. With its wholly inadequate, absolutely inexplicable behaviour, it forced national governments to take the necessary measures and close internal borders one after the other. A large part of you never understood that in order for internal borders to be open, there must be tightly guarded external borders. You can't protect these two at the same time, you can't ask hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants to come here undisturbed and have secure internal borders. This can not happen, it is a utopia and proved it to you and the situation with the panic and hysteria of this crisis. Moreover, the absolutely irresponsible behaviour of the governments of the Netherlands or now the Netherlands, germany, which with its internal problems hold Romania, holds Bulgaria, holds Croatia, keeps Malta out of the Schengen area, can no longer be mentioned. This is hypocrisy and double standard and must be a complex end.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr When we discuss Schengen, we must not forget that it is not just a question of free movement within the EUROPEAN Union and of having holiday plans without a passport in your pocket. Schengen has been and continues to be associated with closing the EU's external borders. It has now made it to levels that are terrible to see. We see it in Ceuta and Melilla, we see it at the Greek border, we see it in the Balkans.  We see a policy that puts the protection of external borders above the protection of people. But our open internal borders cannot be based on crime, violations and brutality at the external borders. Unfortunately, one of the worst examples today is the Croatia presidency, where the partly EU-funded border police are committing systematic illegal push backs. I've been there myself, I've seen it. The Commission has a responsibility to investigate this, but also to put an end to Croatia's Schengen membership. A country should not be rewarded – no country, Croatia or anything else – if human rights are violated at the EU's external borders.

name: Lena DÜPONT
text: – Mr President, I was three when the Berlin Wall fell. I was 13 when Schengen became an integral part of the Amsterdam Treaty. I was about to finish school when 10 new Member States joined our European family. Europe was always part of my life. I have experienced it as open, as free and as a promising continent and to be honest, I never expected to see border controls again.  Yet, understandably due to the nature of the pandemic, and the force with which it hit us, closing borders without coordination caused chaos at the beginning, and even long—forgotten hard rhetoric came up again.  The good thing is, we experienced how closely connected we are already, not only across border regions, not only economically, and we saw that Schengen, that our freedom, is vulnerable, that it is invaluable, and that we need to protect it.  Luckily, Schengen is getting back on track. Europe is getting back on track, with a lot of work ahead of us. So let us draw the obvious lessons learned in the past weeks. Let’s prepare Schengen better and make full use of it for Europe’s recovery. Let’s make Europe come out stronger. (Applause)

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Mr President. In March, for the first time, we may have felt for the first time really seriously how fragile the freedom guaranteed by Schengen is and which we have taken for granted up to now. The emergency situation has understandably required extraordinary solutions, including internal border controls. However, the way in which the Member States have closed their borders, in a natural, uncoordinated manner, often without a clear legal basis, has only unnecessarily undermined the trust that we have built for years, decades in Schengen, and in us themselves. It must probably be realised that Schengen is not really some luxury, nice to have, in good weather, but a cornerstone of the European Union, of our freedoms and, of course, of the single market. And none of this will be sustainable when the first instinct of governments in any crisis situation will always be to unilate and immediately close internal borders. We must learn from this experience. And now is the moment when we have to work to strengthen the resilience of the Schengen area.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Mr President, Schengen, who would have believed in the success of the name of this charming little Luxembourg town, located in the triangle of the French, German and Luxembourg borders? Schengen has become a symbol of a Borderless Europe. Moving from one country to another has become so natural that we no longer even imagined the meaning of having to stop and justify ourselves. The Achievement of Schengen is, as far as individual freedom is concerned, an invaluable achievement, a small, not excuse me, a real wonder of European unity. So let's preserve it. The COVID-19 pandemic has certainly justified the movement bans imposed on people in Europe. Create a health cordon around an outbreak, what could be more normal? It coincides with a border between countries, it is a salutary aid. But how can we justify closing a border where the epidemic situation is the same on one side and the other? It would not occur to me to condemn that certain countries, in a panic, reacted by withdrawal. Let's say it's the irrational human and let's be forgiving. But then, as soon as possible, countries must reopen the internal borders to Schengen, it is above all necessary that, beyond the crisis of COVID-19, some countries do not misunderst the possibility, except in truly exceptional cases, of closing their borders. It's still...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Dear Chairman, freedom of movement for more than 400 million people is one of the cornerstones of modern Europe.  The global pandemic has, understandably, temporarily raised internal borders again, but Europe as we know it does not exist without free movement, which is crucial both for economic recovery, tourism, but also for our European way of life. I am pleased that the European Parliament has provided strong support and further expansion of Schengen to all Member States through a resolution. This is also very important for Croatia, which is ready to become part of the largest free movement space in the world, as established by the European Commission last year. Even today, however, we have had the opportunity to hear attacks on my country for an effective policy of protecting the Longest Land Border of the European Union.  However, I believe that Croatian and all other European citizens will soon enjoy all the advantages of Croatian Schengen membership, better transport connectivity, stronger economic co-operation, but also even better protection of external borders.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. If you, like me, had lived at the border for three months now, you would have been very consternated to see how Schengen has been trampled underfoot legally, in terms of content and symbolism. If Member States react with purely national border closure measures, even in times of crisis, they either have not spoken to each other beforehand or they have no confidence in each other – or both, and that is bad. And nothing has been agreed, either in the case of the closure of borders or the opening up of various economic sectors, nor in the merging of families, nor in the introduction of exit strategies over time. This has led to a patchwork of control measures, of protective measures, of new regulations that no one could understand or understand. Do it like the citizens in my constituency in eastern Belgium: you have submitted a petition calling for 'Schengen 2.0', which in future will prevent borders from being closed, even in pandemic times, so that these border areas can once again become common areas.

name: Ylva Johansson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Schengen means freedom and Schengen is based on mutual trust. Schengen is a major achievement, and this is shown by the great engagement in this Parliament for this issue and for Schengen coming back to a fully functioning Schengen area. When this first Schengen agreement was signed 35 years ago, there were millions of Europeans that didn’t even have the right to leave their own country. The last few months have reminded us what Europe looks like without free movement.  Now slowly and responsibly we are regaining our freedoms. We cannot take the freedom of movement for granted. Nor, for that matter, the significant benefits of European integration. We need to work hard every day to preserve and protect our common European project. To begin with, I would like to see the necessary decision in Council to welcome the waiting Member States into Schengen, but in the long run, we have to do better than a return to the status quo. And it must go without saying that, of course, all Member States, all Schengen members and all those that would like to be members of Schengen have to fully respect their fundamental rights and the European acquis of course.  A well-functioning Schengen area depends on mutual trust among Member States and on a correct and efficient implementation of the Schengen acquis. Differences in one Member State can affect all Member States and subsequently put the Schengen area at risk.  We must continue to make sure the Schengen legal framework is fit for purpose, so that it can meet new challenges such as the current health emergency.  First, through better and more correct implementation. That includes alternatives for internal border checks, such as police controls inside the territory supported by technology and reinforced cross-border cooperation and information exchange between law enforcement authorities. To promote trust and then encourage exchange we will propose a renewed dialogue with all Member States and regular high-level political debates on the state of Schengen with Parliament and the Council. I am ready to continue to work closely, together with all of you in this House, towards this important goal.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the questions surrounding the application of internal border controls are vital for the preservation of the Schengen acquis. Therefore, the Presidency, on behalf of the Council, is very much looking forward to working closely with the European Parliament and the Commission on providing for a legally-sound and operationally-correct structure that would meet all the concerns of the two co—legislators. The Ministers of Home Affairs agreed, at an informal video conference on 5 June, to proceed in a coordinated, transparent and phased manner in line with the principles of proportionality and non—discrimination and based on the criteria defined in the Commission communication. A broad majority of the Member States and the Schengen associate countries lifted controls at the internal borders and ended the related travel restrictions by 15 June. The rest have expressed their intention to do that by the end of this month.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 136(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Friday, 19 June 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Marc ANGEL
text: in writing. – The Schengen Agreement is not just one of the most important achievements of the EU, but also a key tool for a proper functioning Single Market. Internal border controls and closures have to be the exception to adequately remedy the serious threat to public policy or internal security. However, the European Parliament had to raise questions too often in the recent times about the legality and proportionality of the introduced and extended internal border controls. Member States’ justification is based on the Covid-19 pandemic as well as on increased levels of migration and/or security threats. We definitely need a more appropriate Union-level coordination. More targeted restrictions applicable at regional level, including cross-border regions, would have been more appropriate and less intrusive. The lack of real communication on Member States’ decisions led us to a situation where information on introduced border controls and restrictions were not correctly communicated to citizens and enterprises. The collateral consequences were huge. The Commission’s responsibility is to exercise appropriate scrutiny over the application of the Schengen acquis, but the Commission also need to be able to provide up-to-date information on Member States’ rules to citizens. In that sense, I also welcome the creation of the ‘Re-open EU’ website.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: in writing. – I am asking you for a package of recovery measures and a Solidarity Fund for Coronavirus: access to finance, including for non-euro area Member States. (estimated, EU GDP will fall by 7.4 %);  the amounts in the package are granted through loans and mainly through grants, direct payments for investments and equity;  carry out an assessment before the end of the recovery strategy and the possibility of the MFF being revised accordingly, mid-term; calculate the new recovery and transformation fund outside the amounts of the next MFF and this recovery fund to be included in a consolidated MFF and with new sources of funding; introducing a list of potential candidates for new own resources: a common consolidated corporate tax base, taxation of digital services, a financial transaction tax, revenue from the Emissions Trading Scheme, a contribution for plastics and a mechanism for adjusting carbon dioxide emissions at the border, but also the elimination of all corrections and rebates, the simplification of VAT-based own resources and the use of fines and other taxes as additional sources of income for the budget Eu.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: Writing. – More coordination and cooperation is needed when reopening internal borders between Member States and there can be no discrimination. As with the closure, some states have taken uncoordinated steps to open borders and opened some borders, leaving others closed, despite recommendations from the European Commission. It will take some time for the entire Schengen area to be fully restored without border control, and we must also prepare for states to coordinate their actions as closely as possible and inform others in advance in the event of a second wave of coronavirus outbreaks.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: Writing. – I largely disagree with the EU's criticism of the restrictions on the free movement of persons in the Schengen area adopted by the Member States in response to the pandemic. Member States were able to react more quickly to the situation that had arisened, in addition, closing their borders only at a time when the disease was spreading within the EU. At the same time, they have more competence in the field of public health and therefore responsibility for managing a crisis situation. They also closed areas within Member States (e.g. Litovel in the Czech Republic, Žehra in the Slovak Republic), which shows that the intention of the Member States was related to the protection of public health, not to efforts to influence the level of integration.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – In recent decades, Europe has not faced such a serious challenge as the COVID-19 crisis. It has put a number of sectors on its knees, and the full consequences of the crisis cannot yet be predicted. One of the biggest challenges was the effective and proper functioning of one of the greatest achievements of our Union– Schengen. I sincerely hope that another call at EP level for the accelerated adoption of Bulgaria and Romania into the Schengen area will not be left on paper alone, such as the resolution of 11.12.2018, and this time indeed to be heard by the Council. Bulgaria's place is in Schengen. We have strictly met all the criteria set and have full access to the Schengen Information System, but we are not yet a full member. Mutual trust between Member States, now more than ever, is a key condition for the effective functioning of the Schengen area, and Bulgaria has repeatedly proven that it securely and reliably protects the EU's external borders. In conclusion, I will again call on the Council to present a new draft decision on the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the Schengen area at land, sea and air borders in order to make Schengen even more effective and to achieve a genuine and complete free space for even more European citizens.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the European protection of frontier workers and seasonal workers in the context of the COVID-19 crisis (2020/2664 (RSP). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches in this debate and that no blue cards are accepted.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, cross—border and seasonal workers support the agriculture, tourism and hospitality industries when labour demand cannot be covered by the host Member State.  Working away from home is hard enough. Protecting this vulnerable group of workers is therefore even more pressing especially during these times of unprecedented challenges following the outbreak of the COVID—19 pandemic.  Confinement and social distancing measures have had a substantial negative effect on the European economy. Unemployment rates have risen within a short period and businesses are facing difficulties, some sectors more than others. Member States have implemented a large number of measures to prevent and mitigate severe economic implications on labour markets and national social security and welfare systems. Many of these measures aim to protect workers in particularly sensitive sectors of the economy.  While the health emergency is slowly receding and confinement measures are gradually being lifted, the economic and social difficulties remain intense. On 5 May, a video conference organised by the Presidency offered the opportunity to employment and social policy Ministers to share their views on existing strategies. While underlining the importance of a quick economic recovery, Ministers expressed their support for strategies built on a coordinated approach, safeguarding employability, supporting businesses and protecting groups in need.  The issue of cross—border and seasonal workers was brought up many times throughout the discussions. This vulnerable group is considered essential for many economic sectors. It has a vital role to play in the economic recovery and its members should not be discriminated against.  The COVID—19 pandemic forced Member States to close their borders temporarily. Nevertheless, Member States and the members of the European Council indicated clearly in a joint statement on 26 March that smooth border management for persons and goods should be assured in order to preserve the functioning of the single market. While some Member States have already lifted all travel restrictions for cross—border and seasonal workers, others have committed to do so as soon as possible. Ensuring safe working conditions is as important as ensuring free movement. It is essential that this vulnerable group of workers enjoy equal treatment to that provided for workers who are nationals of the host Member State. They should receive adequate protection equipment and, where provided, they should be offered adequate accommodation in compliance with social distancing measures. Moreover, workers should be trained and informed about changes and new procedures.  Member States are also committed to ensuring access to affordable social security for all citizens in cross—border situations. The revision of regulations on the coordination of the social security system would further facilitate the free movement of workers and would act as a catalyst for modernising the national social security system.  I would like to thank Parliament for keeping these problems faced by cross—border and seasonal workers high on the agenda. I look forward to this debate.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the free movement of workers is a key principle of the EU internal market. Millions of Europeans live or work in a Member State other than that of their nationality. We estimate that more than half a million workers are covering seasonal work in the EU. The COVID—19 crisis has led to unprecedented measures across EU Member States, having a direct impact on the free movement of workers, as was shown in the previous debates.  The role of the Commission is clear – ensure free movement of workers. In this context, on 30 March the Commission published guidelines concerning the exercise of the free movement of workers. The goal was for frontier, posted and seasonal workers exercising critical occupations to have unhampered access to their workplace. We talk a lot about frontline workers and I have to repeat that among these frontline workers there are a lot also of seasonal workers who have played an indispensable role and have worked for critical goods and services like, for instance, foods.  To ensure further clarity regarding social security, the Commission also published a fact sheet of questions and answers, including information for the attention of frontier and posted workers affected by the restrictions on free movement related to COVID—19. Based on the dialogue with Member States and stakeholders, we note that the guidelines have had a positive effect. We continue to monitor that the measures adopted by the Member States are necessary and proportionate for the fight against the spread of the virus and non—discriminatory.  Important sectors of the European economy, in particular the agricultural and tourism sectors, require the support of seasonal workers for specific periods of the year. Seasonal workers are often vulnerable to abuses and precarious working and living conditions, including health and safety, access to public services and decent housing, infringement of labour law and inadequate social security coverage. They are also more exposed to undeclared work, in particular in the form of unregistered employment.  The COVID—19 pandemic rendered more visible and acute the problems that many seasonal workers have faced for longer periods. While the situation has been improving recently, significant problems for seasonal workers still persist and need to be addressed. The principle applied to seasonal workers is very, very clear – equal treatment and no discrimination of EU mobile workers compared with national workers. This ensures the best protection for EU mobile workers, including for cross—border and seasonal workers. It means, for seasonal workers, they have exactly the same rights as nationals or residents of the Member State in which they work.  Equal treatment requires proper application of national labour law, including those laws which result, from EU directives, to mobile workers. Given that certain sectors of the economy, and especially the agricultural sector, require the support of seasonal workers from other Member States, the Commission asked Member States to exchange information and establish specific procedures to ensure smooth circulation for such workers. In this respect, I welcome the joint declaration on the protection of seasonal workers signed on 15 May by the European social partners in agriculture. I also welcome the announcement by a Member State to adapt its national legislation and to better control its application.  Our data confirms that the seasonal activities are exposed to undeclared work, often associated with abuses or limited access to social rights and health and safety for workers. In this context, it is essential to raise workers’ and employers’ awareness towards the benefits of declared work and the transition to declared work. This is actually the focus of the EU for Fair Work campaign of the European platform on tackling undeclared work. Europe can also play a role in this context by developing actions with a focus on activities for cross—border workers, seasonal workers and, especially, young people. In the near future, both the platform and the US—European coordination office will be transferred to the European Labour Authority (ELA). Once fully operational, the ELA will assist Member States and the Commission in the effective application and enforcement of Union law related to labour mobility across the Union and the coordination of social security systems within the Union.  One of the aims of the EU rules on social security coordination is to ensure that persons who work in two or more Member States, such as seasonal workers, are subject to the legislation of the Member State with which they have the closest links, promoting stable and continuous social security coverage. Frequent changes in the applicable social security legislation may create an obstacle to the free movement of workers.  I am convinced that the mutual assistance and cooperation between Member States, such as the conclusion of bilateral agreements or making available information in the language of the seasonal workers on social security issues is essential to protect the rights of seasonal workers. The revision of the Social Security Regulation for which the Commission made a proposal back in 2016 is still being discussed between Parliament and Council. I am fully committed to help you finalising this important modernisation of the rules as soon as possible. I also want to repeat my full support for the introduction of a European social security number, requested in your draft resolution.  Let me also make an important point on the health and safety of workers. Given the unprecedented crisis we are going through, this is one of the issues where we cannot fail our citizens. We have solid EU legislation on health and safety at work that applies to all workers, independently of the country where they work, the duration of the assignment or the precise tasks carried out. Ensuring the health and safety of workers is our shared responsibility. It is the employer’s obligation to comply with all requirements and assess all possible risks at work, including new ones, and to put in place adequate preventive and protective measures. The completeness of this evaluation is particularly important in sectors where workers may be particularly exposed. Employers are also obliged to provide workers with related information as well as necessary protective equipment and hygiene products. Besides the guidelines on seasonal workers under preparation by the Commission, the EU has taken numerous steps to support Member States in this regard. But I have to add that it is Member States’ responsibility to control the application of the rights and labour standards which are also applicable to seasonal workers.  The EU European Agency for Health and Safety at Work has published guidance addressing COVID—19 at the workplace, as well as the safe and healthy return to workplaces after COVID. These documents assist employers in dealing with health and safety aspects at work. They also refer to the relevant national guidance for specific sectors and occupations, including those that are particularly susceptible to employ seasonal workers.  I assure you that the protection of workers’ health and safety is one of my main priorities for the years to come. I will be working closely with the members of the European Parliament, notably in view of updating the strategic framework of health and safety at work that will provide us with opportunities to look at post—COVID—19 health and safety implications at the workplace, including for the most vulnerable workers.  We are not forgetting that many seasonal workers are third country nationals and the COVID—19 crisis has had a significant impact on the possibility for these workers to enter the Union. The Commission considers that these workers, in particular in the agricultural sector, often have an essential function. Therefore, already in March, we recommended Member States to authorise the entry of non—EU seasonal workers in agriculture, despite the closure of the EU external border.  I welcome your resolution as an important contribution to future policy making. We want to achieve the same goal, ensuring that the rights of seasonal workers are protected, that the EU rules are enforced, and that the pillar of social rights applies to everybody.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, we often hear it from the populists in this house: Schengen must be on the scrapheap and its borders must be closed. That is their vision for Europe. Unfortunately, we have been trying to imagine that vision for the past few months. And what turns out? That vision of the future, that dream of Le Pen, Baudet and Wilders is a nightmare for millions of ordinary Europeans. Relatives who couldn't bury their loved ones because a container on the border is choking the road. Strawberries and asparagus rotting on the field because the seasonal workers they come to harvest don't cross the border. Border entrepreneurs who are being driven into bankruptcy because they have nowhere to go. You won't know what you're missing until you don't have it anymore. A harsh observation, but also an important lesson. Don't fall into the "close borders" frame of the nexitcall bells in this house. Let us cherish our achievements and continue to work together towards a truly fair labour market, a cross-border market, where hard work is rewarded, where decent housing is the norm, where rogue businesses are tackled and rights are protected. That is my vision for europe!

name: Gabriele BISCHOFF
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Yesterday, hundreds of new Corona infections were reported in Germany's largest meat factory. It bafflyses me and it shows that companies like Tönnies have learned nothing from the crisis and are acting completely irresponsibly. Now some are also trying to shift the blame to the Romanian and Bulgarian workers concerned: they have introduced the virus across the border. Populism is spreading, and we really need to put an end to these conditions. That is why this resolution is a good step. But it's not enough. We need really tough measures. We need to improve EU law where there are gaps, and we need to enforce the law better again. However, I would like to make another appeal to all the mobile workers, to cross-border workers: please do not lose hope of a fair and free European labour market, for fair mobility, because of the closure of the border and the situation. We in Parliament are committed to making changes here.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I want to correctly identify the subject matter of this resolution. Seasonal and cross-border workers are the heart of which pumps energy to many sectors of the European economy. They are citizens who leave for a shorter or longer time from their families in Romania, Bulgaria, Poland, Portugal or Spain and help to operate important industries from other Member States. They are also financial support for those they leave at home, for their families and children.  We have, in the European Union, whole sectors that depend on seasonal workers. We have seen in the crisis that we are going through that when these citizens cannot move between borders, food production, transport, many tourism services or other social, care and medical services are at risk.  I say all these things to understand the importance of these workers to the Union, to the Member States, to larger or smaller farms, to construction firms, to hospitals, hotels or transport firms. For these reasons, I believe that protecting them, where they work, is part of a minimal respect that we owe to these people without which many key economic sectors would be blocked.  However, we have seen in this crisis that many of the seasonal workers are accommodated in squalid conditions, that they are not provided with minimum hygiene conditions and, after they become ill, do not get adequate medical treatment. I have even seen people who have died because of negligence and the fact that their social rights are not respected. That is why, on behalf of the Renew Group, we have initiated this resolution and I am pleased that we have broad support for this.  We owe it to these people with the clarity of the rules in which they operate, with the constant monitoring of accommodation conditions and with the suspension of the activity of companies that try to trick them. European coordination of European legislation is needed and here, Commissioner, I am counting on you. We need to work together, the Commission, Parliament and the Council to give guidance... (The President has withdrawn the speaker's word)

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this resolution, which aims to regulate the free movement and protection of workers, regardless of their status, is a problem. Once again, the commission strives to enshrine the almost divine character of the free movement of workers, and thus of seconded work. The recitals of the resolution establish the need to implement the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination, which opposes the principle of a national priority that is so dear to us. To classify detached work, border workers and seasonal workers in the same category is to force our hand on a text that contradicts two fundamental principles to the interests of our compatriots: to abolish seconded work and to put in place a national priority.

name: Petra DE SUTTER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, this pandemic highlights precarious working conditions for 17 million mobile workers in the EU, of whom hundreds of thousands are cross-border, frontier and seasonal workers. Better social protection was already needed before this crisis, but the lack of safety measures on asparagus or strawberry farms, or in slaughterhouses in the Netherlands or Germany, opened many eyes. Health and safety measures against COVID-19 are not always respected at the workplace, and that is why written instructions like display notices must be used. Crossing borders must also be easy for them, and a better coordination of social security systems has become a matter of high urgency. These workers are in the front line: in hospitals and nursing homes in Austria for example, where many female health workers from Romania and Bulgaria work overtime. They provide a vital workforce. We must provide them with vital social, and health and safety, protection. This is a matter of social justice.

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Border and seasonal workers have been particularly affected by the coronavirus. Due to closed borders, quarantine obligations, sometimes without the possibility of returning to the country, without health care and livelihoods, they were at a higher risk of getting sick. They are also more dependent on employers and temporary employment agencies than others. Their accommodation conditions are bad. They work in difficult conditions and often breach the cross-border and seasonal rights of workers in terms of their working time, minimum wage, health and safety standards. This shows the problems faced by seasonal workers, most often from Eastern Europe. The pandemic has also shown how necessary and underestimated workers depend on in many sectors. It is time to appreciate them, to improve the image of this work, and to propose solutions that will end the scale of abuses already occurring before the pandemic. What does the European Commission have in this regard... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen we are going to vote on a resolution on the rights of seasonal and seconded cross-border workers and I am particularly pleased to be able to co-introduce it not only with the left, but also with the right and even the Liberals.  I think that is great, because for some of you, this may be the first time you will admit that the top priority in the market is detrimental to workers' rights. Of course, you are not yet ready to talk about social dumping - if you change your mind, an amendment has been tabled, you can vote on it - but I still want to encourage and applaud the step you are taking today.  Now you say that the coronavirus crisis has opened your eyes to the suffering and exploitation of mobile workers in Europe. I don't really believe that. I think what made you move was the pressure you felt, the pressure and rage of these exploited workers, stacked on each other in small vans or even entire flights, from Romania to Germany for example.  But hey, it doesn't matter what made you move. What matters to me is how we can continue, because here we are once again faced with a non-binding resolution. So you are voting this, all right, now let us take the next step and adapt the European rules so that, in fact, workers' rights are given priority over economic freedoms and the market.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the pandemic has shown us in recent weeks that the European labour market is much more integrated than we imagine. We have understood that, without the free movement of workers, especially seasonal workers and cross-border workers, entire production and strategic sectors for the European Union are in danger of being blocked.  Since leaving his country of origin with green corridors, the worker has the need to be protected with high standards of protection, housing, working conditions and remuneration, up to full recognition of his acquired rights in terms of social security, which for us must fall back into the country where the worker is working and where he pays his taxes. In our opinion, the Union must promote the harmonisation of national labour laws in order to resolve wage dumping, but also to tackle the new dumping that is advancing and which is based precisely on the health and safety of workers. I believe that we can support this resolution, especially if it can form the basis for new legislative measures to better protect European workers and to eliminate the unfair competition that still unfortunately characterises the internal market today ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Dennis RADTKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The political buzzword of the hour is "systemically important". To use it, we have seen in recent weeks how systemically important the European internal market and also the free movement of workers are for our national economies. On the other hand, however, we have also seen how fragile this system is. Czech nurses and doctors working in German hospitals suddenly had to choose between work and family overnight because the borders were closed. German and French farmers were concerned about their crops because they were no longer receiving harvesters. And as if all this were not enough, we have also been reminded of the state of the meat industry in Germany and the Netherlands – conditions that were known, but which have now overflowed the barrel. That is why it is good that we as a Parliament are presenting this resolution today. It is now up to the Commission, and above all to the Member States, to put what has been set in motion here into action and to deliver.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, you wonder what kind of thought is going on in the minds of someone who makes migrant workers from Poland and Romania work 14 hours a day, 42 days in a row. What inspires someone who threatens to put someone on the street, because this migrant worker wants to call in sick with a fever. What do you think about when you dump a Romanian migrant worker on the side of the road and leave it to his own devices in a foreign country? Unfortunately, these are examples from the past few weeks from my country, the Netherlands. You think, as far as I'm concerned, "What moves people?" But you don't thank people. You don't dump them on the street. People are not a throwaway item. As far as I am concerned, the temporary bosses, the agricultural sector and the food industry have fallen through the ground. From east to west we now agree: something needs to be done about this! Our resolution contains proposals to tackle these abuses and exploitation. Bind the temporary employment agencies to rules with a revision of the broadcasting directive. Set standards around decent housing with privacy and a lease. And go maintain it with more inspectors in the risk sectors and with a European social security number. I trust that Commissioner Schmit will immediately address the abuses that we are currently seeing and that he will get to work on this resolution. The European Member States must now come up with measures. They need to act, because working in another European country is, as far as I am concerned, a great asset. It's an employee's right. But then everyone in Europe must be able to be sure of a healthy and safe workplace.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: – Mr President, this resolution initiated by the Renew Europe Group and which I had the honour to coordinate is dedicated to cross-border and seasonal workers, Romanians, Poles, Bulgarians or other nationalities, who had to die in containers, be infected with Covid-19 and suffer in unsuitable conditions so that today we can all unite, east and west , north and south, left and right, so that we can react firmly and consensusly.  The crisis has shown us how vulnerable we are. Unfortunately, these vulnerabilities have persisted for years. Quite! Cross-border workers are one of the most powerful symbols of the European Union, a symbol for freedom of movement and the prosperity of the internal market, making an essential contribution to Europe's economic sectors.  We hear you and we will fight, today and in the future, for your right to freedom of movement, for the right to follow your European dream, to have a living, a decent home, a decent life, to work in the labour market anywhere in Europe and to be respected and treated indiscriminately. All of us, Parliament, the Commission, the Member States have a moral and legal responsibility to ensure everything you need now and in the future.

name: Alessandro PANZA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I must say that I agree, albeit with some reservations, with the content of the resolution that has been tabled on the protection of cross-border workers, a working category particularly affected by the Covid-19 crisis. As far as Italy is concerned, more than one hundred thousand workers go across the border every day to work in other countries, such as France, Austria and even San Marino. Of these, however, more than 70 000 work in Switzerland. That is why, on the one hand, the call for this resolution must also be extended to neighbouring states, such as Switzerland or the United Kingdom, in order to ensure decent working conditions and appropriate protection measures, in order to protect all frontier workers, in particular seasonal workers who, by the nature of their contractual basis, fall within a particularly fragile range.  On the other hand, we hope that the States will apply concretely and not only at the talk of protective measures for those frontier and seasonal workers, who have lost their jobs due to the Covid-19 crisis. In all this, of course, there is no need to regularise illegal immigrants, as has happened in Italy, the only result of which has been to increase illegal entry into the European Union.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, with the COVID-19 crisis, Member States and the European Union have been responsible for numerous violations of the rights of mobile workers. By abruptly closing the borders, the most precarious among the precarious, migrant workers from third countries, found themselves alone in the face of the abuses of some employers: without social coverage, without resources and in indecent housing conditions, sometimes without the possibility of returning home. However, these people are essential to our economy, to our agriculture, to the construction of our countries, and this treatment is not worthy of European values. On European soil, equal rights for all must be definitively proclaimed. This resolution is a step forward, but more needs to be done. It is time for Europe to move from the exploitation of these migrant workers to the recognition of their contribution to our economy and our food sovereignty. It is time for equal rights to become a concrete, genuine and verifiable reality.

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: – Mr President. We have 1.3 million cross-border workers and 2 million posted workers throughout the European Union. And during the corona, when the borders between the various states of the European Union were closed, we could see how vulnerable these people had become. Oftentimes they have had to choose whether to stay with their family and lose their jobs or, conversely, whether they go to work, remain isolated from the family for months. Of course, some segments, such as agriculture, social services or the transport of goods, have suffered from an acute shortage of workers by the fact that many have not got to work. These people are in permanent social insecurity because they stand in two or more social systems. They are often discriminated against. Let's look at the Austrian indexation of family allowances. For the next crisis, we must learn lessons, make borders clearer for them and finally coordinate social security systems, including the digital interconnection of systems.

name: Leila CHAIBI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to talk to you about Yasmine. Yasmine picks up the melons, apricots and peaches we like to eat right now. Yasmine works 260 hours a month, she gets paid crumbs. She has days without a break, so when she wants to eat, she has to hide in the toilet. Yasmine is sick, she has multiple sclerosis, because of all these years spent working in these conditions. In addition, it is not even covered by social security.  What I am talking about is the daily lives of hundreds of seconded, seasonal workers, workers who come from Spain and who are sometimes from Guinea, Colombia, who are seconded to France, Germany or elsewhere to pick fruit and vegetables. The COVID-19 crisis has exacerbated the difficulties faced by these exploited workers, who have often been housed during this crisis in extreme conditions of misery, conducive to the spread of coronavirus. The exploitation of these men and women must stop. It is unacceptable and it is high time that the European Union guaranteed respect for the rights of these workers and repealed the detached work directive.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, colleagues, seasonal and cross-border workers are an indispensable category for many sectors of activity. During the Covid-19 pandemic, their lack put many farms in European Union countries at risk. At the same time, however, in many states, they have ended up in difficult situations that have endangered their lives and social security.  Commissioner, the European Union must find mechanisms to make it mandatory for the Member States of destination to ensure safe working conditions and to guarantee adequate wages for the work performed. Accommodation conditions must comply with legal and reasonable living standards and social security must guarantee their real protection in the event of illness, including in the event of a pandemic.  It is also necessary to set up telephone lines available in several languages of the countries of the European Union, so that those workers can, once again, verify their rights and obligations, as well as to complain about abuses or breaches of their employment contracts.

name: Estrella DURÁ FERRANDIS
text: – Mr President, the current pandemic has exposed that the mobility of migrant workers in Europe does not always respect equal treatment with nationals. I am referring to both intra-European workers and those from third countries, as is the case with temporary workers in the agricultural sector, who have contributed so much to the supply of commodities during this crisis. We have known cases of extreme, precarious and life-threatening working conditions. It is therefore necessary to detect possible abuses and fraud because, even though they are minority, they are very bleeding and damage the image of the sector and create unfair competition. It also occurs in other sectors where fraudulent labour intermediaries operate, who recruit workers in one country to take them to another in working and unprotected conditions, such as Spanish, Romanian and Bulgarian workers in the Netherlands. Europe cannot afford this. All workers without exception must enjoy equal treatment, social protection, decent working conditions and access to State aid, regardless of their country of origin or destination.

name: Sylvie BRUNET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the initiative of this resolution on the protection of seasonal border workers in the event of the COVID-19 crisis.  We do not discover the situation with this crisis, but it has amplified it. While the principle of the free movement of European workers within the European Union is an essential right, it must not contravene the principle of equal treatment between them. The coronavirus crisis has unfortunately revealed the existence of abuses and breaches of European legislation, which each Member State has a responsibility to enforce.  I would therefore like to stress the need to ensure that seasonal and border workers have effective social protection, as well as adequate health and safety conditions. Finally, I would like to recall the major role of the European Labour Authority, labour inspections and a rapid and adequate transposition of the revised directive on seconded workers.

name: Miroslav RADAČOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President. I support, in its entirety, the motion for a resolution concerning foreign and seasonal workers. It is common knowledge that seasonal workers in particular come from socially weaker groups, that they come from eastern European countries and come from third countries. It is also common knowledge that they work on short-term contracts, have poor working conditions, often the minimum wage. It is therefore necessary to address these facts so that the working conditions of these employees, who make up a significant income for the countries in which they work, are sufficiently acceptable and in line with European legislation. We must also think about the future and think that perhaps one day such conditions and seasonal employment will also apply to men, women from Paris, Sweden and other countries, that they will come to eastern European countries to work. That is, that they have the same conditions as they are now.

name: Guido REIL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which There is a new Corona hotspot in Germany, and the meat industry is once again affected.  600 newly infected – 7,000 employees are in quarantine at Tönnies, Germany's largest meat company, and most of these employees come from Romania and Bulgaria. And what does the Prime Minister of North Rhine-Westphalia – the Christian Democrat Prime Minister – say now: the slave-like working conditions and the slave-like living conditions of these people are not responsible for the new infections. She said her journey home at the weekend was responsible for this.  So I'm horrified, I'm absolutely appalled by such a statement. Freedom of movement with Romania and Bulgaria has indeed led to real problems in North Rhine-Westphalia: wage dumping, undeclared work, social fraud, prostitution, crime. But to accuse these people of going home and getting infected there is, personally, xenophobic. I am appalled by such a prime minister and such a country father.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Hundreds of new Corona cases in a slaughterhouse in Gütersloh. And indeed, the first thing that comes to mind for the North Rhine-Westphalian Prime Minister, Armin Laschet, is that the Romanian and Bulgarian workers themselves would have brought that with them. Sorry, but that's just not possible! Firstly, because it serves an old xenophobic narrative, namely that foreigners bring any kind of disease. Secondly, because Armin Laschet is taking responsibility for this.  In a united Europe, it is, of course, the responsibility of the North Rhine-Westphalian Prime Minister to keep an eye on the Bulgarian and Romanian workers. Because they often work in inhumane conditions to a starvation wage and are crammed into mass accommodation. That is why we need prime ministers who care about the rights of workers, whatever their nationality, and a European Employment Agency that can monitor and enforce existing law. And if all this is not enough, then we are not afraid to set the standards here, because we must finally put an end to this exploitation!

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin this speech by recognising the great work of the temporary workers in the field. This crisis has reminded us how fundamental they are. In Spain, according to agricultural organizations, fruit crops could not be harvested because of the coronavirus. 100,000 posts of these jobs could not be filled. Jobs under the law.  That is why I am outraged that part of my nation's social-community government, with absolute misinformation, accuses Spanish farmers of slavery. This accusation only seeks to criminalize and damage the image of agriculture before Spanish society, which considers it an example and a strategic sector, especially after seeing how it has prevented the desupply of our shops and supermarkets.  And we cannot accept this accusation, let alone coming from a government that, while 40,000 Spaniards died — 20,000 of them elderly in their residence without hospital support - and while 59,000 toilets and thousands of police and civilian guards were infected, denied them the most basic security measures. Instead of accusing our farmers, what the government should do is ask for forgiveness. If there is one who has the right to accuse is undoubtedly the Spanish people to their ineffable government.

name: Chiara GEMMA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are well aware that the measures taken by the Member States to contain and combat the spread of the virus have had very serious consequences for cross-border and seasonal workers in the States where they were employed. I am thinking of having found themselves immediately and suddenly without income, housing, transport, health care. I would like to address a special thought to seasonal workers in the agricultural sector, who are often victims of caporalato. Unfortunately, this scourge is widespread in the regions of my southern Italy. This resolution is a clear and acceptable response, given the serious problems faced by these categories of workers.  I hope, then, that the Commission and the Member States will guarantee full protection of rights, penalising any discrimination against workers, and that the Council will guarantee the resources necessary to boost employment and support protection against penalised workers and companies.

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, as you said earlier, the free movement of workers is a fundamental principle of the European Union. When we talk about seasonal workers or workers crossing borders to go to work, we are talking about people, people with families, with needs, who depend on their wages, about people who are currently watching us with the expectation that, as the European Parliament, as Europe, we will do everything possible to protect them. Our role here today is to give them the message that we understand their needs, that we take care to secure their jobs, to protect them, that we stand by them and not against them. This message must be sent today from this Chamber.

name: Marc ANGEL
text: Mr President, the COVID-19 crisis has highlighted a range of abuses and structural problems related to worker mobility in Europe. I welcome the resolution which puts employers, Member States and Europe in front of their responsibilities. On the employers' side, there is too much abuse and exploitation of seasonal workers above all. On the Member Side, public services are weakened by austerity and this has rendered social and labour inspection services ineffective. Finally, on the European side, several good recommendations were published throughout the crisis, but what about their follow-up by the Member States, what about compliance with European and national legislation on worker mobility? We socialists demand more transparency. We encourage the Commission to continue to analyse the impact of the measures taken following the closure of the borders and respect for workers' social and tax rights, and we hope that the conclusions will lead to an action plan including legislation. Finally, on behalf of the Socialist and Democratic Group, I would like to thank the many associations and NGOs as well as the social partners for their valuable emergency assistance to workers throughout this crisis.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, the COVID-19 epidemic, as you know, has dealt a blow to the economy of our continent. In the midst of this widespread slump, I am speaking today to defend our youth. In a country like France, which has a million unemployed, our students, our young graduates are experiencing very serious difficulties.  How many young people will not be able to find a summer job to allow them to live the rest of the year? How many students will not find an internship to validate their degree? How many young graduates will complete their studies and look for months, but years before finding a job in their field? How many young people, in general, dream of leaving this continent for a better future?  Meanwhile, the European Union is forcing us to allow, to respect the most vile rules of globalist free trade, to allow tens of thousands of seconded workers into our country, to let even more economic migrants in, who are given priority over employment.  Before the European Union, and its Commission, reimpose its unbearable doctrine, think of our youth, think of our students, think of our graduates. The story we will remember from this assembly is...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)
