name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The man was in his mid-fifties, he came from Romania. He collapsed on the assembly line, the foreman insulted him as to why he was lying on the ground. He had to walk eight kilometres to his accommodation and look for a doctor on his own. Here in Germany, there is no one to support him.  More than 17 million Europeans are cross-border workers: in agriculture, care, slaughterhouses, shipyards and cleaners. Many of them are very poorly paid, have no social protection and poor health protection. We must not only be interested in their fate when the coronavirus breaks out in German slaughterhouses. It is scandalous that people are being exploited by companies such as Tönnies or Vion.  The German Federal Government must use its Presidency to stand up for the rights of all people, all EU workers, and the EU Commission must look and take more action for workers. It is good that we, as a Parliament, are starting this with this resolution. Let us now work together to ensure that their situation is improved.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The pandemic has sometimes exacerbated in a tragic way what the European Parliament has been talking about for a very long time. This, of course, changes systematically, but where it was bad, it was even worse. This is an excellent opportunity to analyse, draw conclusions and give recommendations. At the same time, we European Parliamentarians should assume ourselves a commitment to solve problems together with our colleagues in the Member States – because, after all, it is the Member States that are responsible, among other things, for controlling companies that improperly protect workers. I hope that the German Presidency will have such meetings of family ministers on its agenda in order to be able to check, analyse and present to us a report that will be the result of reflection on everything that has happened in recent times.

name: Gheorghe FALCĂ
text: – Mr President, colleagues, at the age of sixteen I was on a school exam, and my family, in order to buy me a bicycle, sent me twenty-one days into seasonal work. I worked with love and thought about the bicycle, without thinking about what my security means. I see things differently today.  With this resolution, we call on the Commission and the Member States to ensure that workers receive adequate protection, by improving working conditions, by respecting accommodation standards, by improving health and safety standards. At the same time, the responsibility of employers and recruitment firms to respect workers' rights must be increased. I thank the rapporteur for taking into account six important points that I have proposed on behalf of Romania's delegation of the EPP.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the pandemic has had a terrible impact on our lives, but it has not affected everyone in the same way. It has in fact made the living and working conditions of those who were already on the margins of the production system more extreme and brutal, although they are an indispensable part of it. The situation in which thousands of seasonal workers and migrant workers live today, particularly in the agricultural sector, is absolutely unacceptable: exploited for starvation pay, without hours, without rights and, in times of Covid-19, without that health protection that must be guaranteed. Often invisible slaves under the daily blackmail of corporals, as has already been mentioned. This requires stronger, faster and more timely responses.  The principle of equal treatment for equal work, which some European regulations also enshrine, must be applied in national legislation, and we need serious and effective controls both on the material conditions in which these people live and work and on the subcontracting chains in which their work is included. Guaranteeing their rights also means stopping social dumping and that odious competition ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rosanna CONTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we need to listen, listen to all those demands that come from our cross-border and seasonal workers, driving away attempts to regularise legal immigrants, as has happened in Italy.  If we wanted to respond seriously to the labour needs of our productive activities, we would have to give priority to the many unemployed citizens affected by the crisis, perhaps considering the possibility of introducing a voucher system to regulate casual jobs and thus reduce the tax burden.  And here I am also referring to those residents who base their income on activities carried out only in certain seasons. I am thinking, for example, of beach goers, ski instructors and all the operators in the tourist sector in coastal areas, such as lifeguards, waiters and cleaners. All of them must be guaranteed decent working conditions regulated by the individual Member States. Only in this way will there be a real prospect of getting out of this crisis.

name: Christian SAGARTZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report The COVID-19 crisis has presented particular challenges for commuters, and I have noticed this in particular because I live in a region where these commuters are subject to very special rules.  I come from Burgenland, a part of Austria that has been on the dead border for a very long time, where we appreciate the coexistence of all the states, that the neighbourhood is lived and that employees are mobile. This is of very central importance, especially where it has been felt in my region: in the area of health and care. It is important today that the European Parliament sends a clear signal to these mobile workers, to seasonal workers, and to send a signal here together, including appreciation. I believe – and this is particularly important – that many people were afraid the moment borders were closed: where should I stay for the next few weeks and perhaps months? At work or with my family? We are grateful that this has been rectified very quickly in many areas and that today the European Parliament is sending out a clear signal.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the achievement of a joint resolution of the European Parliament is an important step to ensure better conditions for seasonal workers and is, in fact, a clear message that we will not tolerate any form of modern slavery. It confirms the messages sent by us Social Democrats on the existence of serious problems and violations of European labour and social rights law.  In the case of Romania, the government itself has endangered the health of hundreds of seasonal workers, in the light of decisions that did not allow the application of European law. The resolution takes over the solutions included in our repeated messages to the European and national institutions and these solutions are supported by more than 50 000 people who have signed our petition to the European institutions.  But the problem is not solved. Romanian workers who took to the streets, those who turned to the court, those who were crammed into planes and coaches have high expectations of us. The European Union must protect all workers and intervene when social rights have been violated, as happened in the case of Romanian workers.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are here talking about seasonal workers in covid emergency and therefore also about border management. Then we can tell each other the truth and tell, for example, what happened in Italy. In this Covid period there have been thousands of irregular immigrants who have landed on our coasts. So let's say that border management didn't exactly work very well. There have been disproportionate costs for quarantine: even ad hoc ferries and with all the comforts to manage the emergency and, therefore, also the reception. There were ad hoc ferries for the management of the reception. No European solidarity, no relocation, no shared management of reception. And then on the seasonal, what did the government do? He decided to do a nice sanatoria, under the pretext of the emergency of seasonal workers in the agricultural sector, with the peace of many Italians in difficulty and without work. So let us say a total failure, both for Italy and for Europe.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Mr President, the COVID crisis has shown how important seasonal workers are to meet the food needs of all European citizens. These workers deserve of course our respect, our recognition and, in this sense, thank you to the rapporteur, thank you for the contribution. It goes in the right direction of their protection and somewhere of their safeguarding, which is part of the whole agricultural system, in quotation marks. Compared to border workers: almost one in two border workers in my area is bordering. I think it is important to be able to make their lives easier in the event of a crisis. There have been many difficulties, particularly at the borders.  It would be a good way to produce perhaps at European level a kind of work-workers'at-border passport to facilitate their controls, also to facilitate the life of companies that have had to multiply the administrative procedures, and therefore organise this, with perhaps different levels. One example could be a 5-star passport, if I may say so, for health care workers who cross the border to meet health needs on both sides of the border. Let's work on this proposal. I think it could improve the lot of everyone.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – Mr President, I have already spoken in this chamber about the need to protect the rights of frontier workers. During the session, we will vote on a very important resolution regarding their rights, the rights of cross-border and seasonal workers as well. By the way, I was one of them, for almost five years.  It is a good step, a step in the right direction. What must follow is concrete action by both the European Union and the Member States, both legislative and non-legislative, and particularly the provision of crucial information.  During the current crisis, they have failed to do so. To help frontier workers from my region in Silesia I had to open a cross-border information point in my office, simply because the public authorities were not there. This is not right. Societies are resilient, but far more so when properly informed.  Public authorities must provide accurate up to date and comprehensive information as a human right.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, honourable Members, we have debated this afternoon an important subject, a subject that goes to the very heart of European integration: the free movement of workers. It's a great asset, it's a great achievement, but it's also a big responsibility.  Unfortunately, in the light of the current crisis, we have seen what we may have guessed before, that there were also unacceptable situations in this free movement, undignified working conditions, unacceptable living and housing conditions. I believe that this debate will help us to address, to solve these problems more effectively, more quickly. It is not a solution, as some have said, to want to repeal the detachment directive, because if we applied that directive, well there would not be these scandalous situations. And besides, it is not the legal situation that is the problem, it is its non-application. It is the fact that controls are absent or insufficient.  So I think it is a call to all, of course to employers, of course to the Member States, to apply the law, to apply European principles. I believe that if we do that, we will have made progress and restored the dignity of all those workers who deserve it.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, to conclude, I would like to reiterate the Council’s support with regard to the free movement of seasonal and cross-border workers, but let me reiterate the conditions for this support, which are providing these workers with a safe working environment, social protection and equal treatment with national workers.  Member States are ready to debate these issues further, together with Parliament and the Commission, seeking the best solution to face the daunting challenges posed by COVID—19.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Madam President Brnjac. That, if I understood correctly, was your last intervention in your capacity under the Croatian Presidency. Thank you for your constant presence. I personally wish you all the best and hope that we will see each other again from time to time. Thank you very much. A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Friday, 19 June 2020. The sitting is suspended until 6.15 p.m. (The sitting was suspended at 4.34 p.m.) Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: in writing. – COVID-19 has tested the normal functioning of the food supply chain. Agriculture as the first and most vulnerable link in this chain has felt a severe shortage of seasonal labour at a time when the Union's internal borders have been completely closed. The crisis has brought to the fore the importance and irreplaceable role of the "invisible" heroes – seasonal workers, who are most often from vulnerable social groups from Eastern Europe. The new CAP and the farm-to-table strategy must take into account the importance of the agricultural and seasonal workers who provide the food at our table. They deserve health and safety at work, fair pay and social protection, as well as access to health services in the countries where they are temporarily resident. Very often these workers fall victim to abuses by unscrupulous employers or intermediaries to find temporary employment. In this respect, it is necessary to ensure transparent access to information, in language which can be understood to them, on employment contracts, social and health rights, support in the event of an accident at work, aid for repatriation, as well as the opportunities available to report abuse and to receive support without fear of reprisals.

name: Atidzhe ALIEVA-VELI
text: in writing. – The pandemic has had a serious negative impact on the Union economy and the world as a whole. However, we cannot deny that some sectors and workers have been hit much more severely than others, and this requires recovery and support measures to be tailored to the difficulties and specificities experienced by individual sectors and workers. Seasonal and cross-border workers face significant difficulties requiring immediate action by the EC and MS in order to provide adequate protection to those who guarantee the Union's food security, as well as those engaged in the provision of goods and services of fundamental importance in key economic sectors. However, I welcome the guidelines announced by the Commission, but I believe that more should be done. We are still reading disturbing stories and hearing about a number of cases where the principle of equal treatment does not apply. There is no harmonised process for reporting abuses and problems, which limits the possibility of making inadmissible practices known. I insist on appropriate protection from COVID-19 and the consequences associated with the disease, including easy access to testing. I call on all countries to take measures to ensure the protection of the health and safety of workers on their journey to the workplace concerned, and to provide them with decent housing conditions, and that the Commission should monitor and monitor their implementation.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – The problems of seasonal workers in Europe are not new. We talk about them periodically and then the subject moves to the fore until the next crisis. New, however, is what has happened in recent months with the wave of Romanian workers, left, in full pandemic, in the unknown, to work in unclear conditions, on the basis of abusive contracts, risking their health and life. For weeks, We have seen hundreds of testimonies in the Romanian media about what they had to endure.  It was the result of a perfect storm, caused by a very weak government, by non-transparent bilateral agreements with other states - which undermines EU principles - and individuals and firms who have tried to take advantage of European chaos, hoping to make easy money on the backs of desperate citizens.  I welcome this resolution and the contribution made by S&D on the topic of seasonals. The Social Democrats must continue to look beyond the institutions and always see the man. Because this man often needs help and the comfort of knowing that, although poor, he will not be disqualified to the rank of second-rate citizen or left behind.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – The free movement of workers is a right of workers and a fundamental principle of the European Union necessary for the proper functioning of the internal market. Labour mobility should not only be free, but also fair. Article 45(2) TFEU lays down the principle of equal treatment, which prohibits any discrimination on grounds of nationality between workers from Member States relating to employment, wages and other working and employment conditions. This principle applies equally to cross-border and seasonal workers who must be treated equally with workers who are nationals of the host Member State, in accordance with EU legislation, in terms of equal rights or equal working conditions or equal protection. We call on the Commission and the Member States to implement measures to ensure that cross-border and seasonal workers, cross-border entrepreneurs and self-employed workers are given adequate protection against COVID-19 and its consequences, including easy access to tests, and that the language they understand is provided with information on the risks and security measures to be taken. We call for measures to ensure their health and safety on the move and adequate housing conditions, ensuring safe distance, not only in their place of residence but also in the workplace, as well as decisions relating to repatriation that would not be taken to the detriment of workers if such decisions were needed.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – The debate on the European protection of cross-border and seasonal workers in times of covid-19 crisis summarises at one point the key issues that the European Parliament is dealing with at its June meeting and the challenges for the future of the EU. The situation of cross-border and seasonal workers has become a topic of emergency resolution with the Covid-19 epidemic, which requires urgent resolution to protect people's rights and the functioning of the European economy. At the same time, it provides direct evidence of the importance of a functioning Schengen system in which there are no internal borders and controls. The free movement of people is one of the EU's four fundamental freedoms, and the current crisis has been reinforced by the fact that this freedom has no real meaning if it is not implemented in a just way in which people's rights are at the forefront. Decent employment in a safe and healthy working environment, coordination of social security systems so that no one falls between the gaps in member states' laws, the care to improve worker information and adequate supervision of the implementation of cross-border and seasonal work, as well as the elimination of prejudice and the reduction of economic and social disparities between and within Member States, must become the topics at the top of the EU priority list. The conference on the future of the EU cannot pass without answering the question of how to strengthen the EU's long-neglected social dimension.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: Written. Seasonal and cross-border workers in Europe are often deprived of their rights to equal treatment and often work with poor working conditions and poor working environments. This must stop. This resolution is a step in the right direction. And I hope that the Commission will take these proposed measures. It is particularly urgent that, during the current pandemic, we now have systematic work environment work in place that protects even the most vulnerable in the labour market. However, as a Social Democrat, I would have liked even clearer demands that EU funds should not go to rogue employers. In my world, not a single euro should go to companies that use European freedoms to exploit fellow human beings. Workers should feel safe in their workplace and have good working conditions – regardless of their type of employment. Consumers should know that when they buy something from the EU, it is free from exploitation of the labour market. And serious companies should know that they do not run the risk of being out-competed by rogue companies simply because they comply with laws, rules and collective agreements. I will continue to work for initiatives at both national and European level that strengthen the conditions for these vulnerable workers.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – Cross-border workers and seasonal workers play an indispensable role in key economic sectors and have been severely affected by member states' measures to control and prevent the spread of the virus, in particular border closures, temporary restrictions and internal border controls. It is important to take measures to protect their health and safety when travelling. The negative image of seasonal workers and cross-border workers must also be combated. On the other hand, employers also need clear rules and Member States should be prepared for possible future waves of Covid19. This also requires guidance and reliable data from the European Commission to help Member States. We strongly support the proposals in this way.  At the same time, unfortunately, the resolution has implicated conceptually incongruous migrant workers among cross-border and seasonal workers. I reject in the strongest possible terms any reference to the 2018 Global Agreement on Safe, Orderly and Orderly Migration, in particular its objectives 5 and 22. However, as improving the situation of the target group of chin reservations is very important, I will abstain in the final vote.

name: Dan-Ştefan MOTREANU
text: in writing. – I call on the European Commission to exercise its role as guardian of the Treaties and to ensure the implementation of the principle of equal treatment laid down in Article 45(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which prohibits any discrimination on grounds of nationality between workers of the Member States with regard to employment, remuneration and working conditions.  The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed the absolutely deplorable conditions under which the majority of seasonal workers operate in Europe 2020, highlighting abuses such as non-compliance with occupational health and safety standards, excessive working time, non-insurance of minimum wages, unsuitable accommodation conditions and the non-transparent and misleading practices of recruitment agencies and local employers. I call on the European Commission to come up with proposals to ensure that workers have clear employment contracts before they leave, to set up a tool to enable workers to report abuses anonymously and to ensure the continuous organisation of joint cross-border inspections at workplaces.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. – The COVID-19 crisis has once again highlighted the already catastrophic working and living conditions of many workers. Especially seasonal and temporary workers such as harvest workers and other cross-border workers such as nurses. It must not be the case that cheap prices are worth more than the health and dignity of people who harvest vegetables or work in the slaughterhouse. With increased controls, common European minimum standards and a European social security number, we must finally create better working conditions. Qualitative work and fair pay must also play an important role in the EUROPEAN Commission's long-term plans. A social Europe must look to all employees, regardless of their origin. It is high time that we put an end to the exploitation of seasonal workers and not only give respect and applause to the system owners, but above all good pay and decent working conditions!

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: I now move on to the announcement of the results of the second voting period we have held.  (The President announces the outcome of the votes of the second voting period.) We now move on to the third voting period, but before we begin, I would like to give the floor to our colleague Mrs Hohlmeier who asked to comment on the motion for a resolution on the reopening of the judicial proceedings against the Prime Minister of the Czech Republic for misuse of European Union funds and potential conflicts of interest (2019/2987(RSP)) (B9-0192/2020).

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We will vote in a time on the motion for a resolution on the resumption of investigations into the Prime Minister of the Czech Republic for the misuse of EU funds and potential conflicts of interest. This motion was drafted across political groups and is based, among other things, on the findings of the CONT mission to the Czech Republic. There, our concerns have been heeded that there is no functioning system in the Czech Republic for preventing and detecting conflicts of interest. Systematic or systemic opacity and a wide division of responsibilities make it extremely difficult to effectively control and avoid conflicts of interest.  In addition, the highest audit authority seems to be severely restricted in its work. Freedom of the media is becoming increasingly problematic and pressure is being exerted on civil servants. The key message of the motion for a resolution is that if a serious conflict of interest is confirmed, it must be resolved immediately.  There are basically three ways of doing this: eliminating the economic interest, ending the receipt of subsidies or abstaining from decisions that may in any way promote the conflict of interest. If this is not possible, only a resignation from office remains.  I therefore recommend voting 'plus' on all separate and separate votes, so as not to weaken the clear message of the motion. EU subsidies are intended to benefit the vast majority of the population, not enrich individual oligarchs.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: We are now in a position to start today's third voting period.  This voting period is therefore open and runs until 19:45.  Voting is carried out in accordance with the same procedure used in previous votes. The results of this third voting period will be announced at 10:15 p.m. (The session is adjourned at 6:38 p.m.).
